{"uri": "8259638683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:41:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:41:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:40:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/cricket/story/former-england-cricketer-graham-thorpe-passes-away-aged-55-2577028-2024-08-05", "title": "Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Thorpe worked as a coach with England after retiring from the game\n\nFormer England cricketer Graham Thorpe has passed away at the age of 55, the England and Wales cricket board confirmed on Monday, August 5. Thorpe played 100 Tests for England from 1993 to 2005 and also was a part of 82 ODIs during that time. Thorpe scored 6,744 runs for England in Tests, and hit 16 centuries during his time with the team at an average of 44.66.\n\nOn Monday, ECB released a statement on their website confirming the demise of Thorpe.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that the ECB shares the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\"\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\"\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport,\" read the statement from ECB.\n\nGraham Thorpe made his first-class debut for Surrey in the summer of 1988 and became a regular player in the 1989 season. He made his England debut in 1993 at age 24, scoring an impressive 114 runs against Australia at Trent Bridge.\n\nThorpe became a key player in England's middle order, with his unbeaten double-century against New Zealand in Christchurch in 2002 standing out as a career highlight. This innings included 28 fours and four sixes.\n\nThough his international career was marked by intermittent appearances, he retired from England duty in 2005. Thorpe then transitioned into coaching, initially in Australia, where he mentored players like Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales. He later joined the England and Wales Cricket Board as a batting coach.\n\nIn March 2022, Thorpe was appointed head coach of Afghanistan's cricket team, but he could not assume the role due to ill As recently as the 2021-22 Ashes tour, Thorpe was England's batting coach. Thorpe also played 81 one-day international and was a stalwart for Surrey in one of their great eras of County Championship success at the turn of the century.\n\nThorpe had not been seen in public since the Professional Cricketers' Association announced in May 2022 that he was \"seriously ill\" and was receiving treatment in hospital.\n\nThe ECB have confirmed on Monday morning that Thorpe died this weekend, just a few days after his 55th birthday. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. {"uri": "8259649832", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:49:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:49:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:47:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.crictracker.com/social-tracker-cricket/former-england-cricketer-graham-thorpe-passes-away-at-55/", "title": "Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe dies passes away at 55", "body": "Former England middle-order batter Graham Thorpe passed away at the age of 55. The England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced the tragic news on Monday, August 05.\n\nThorpe, a stalwart of English cricket, had many brilliant moments during his illustrious career. Making his Test debut against Australia at Nottingham in July 1993, he went on to play 100 Test matches for England. His international career spanned over a decade, concluding with his final Test match against Bangladesh in June 2005.\n\nThe left-handed batter's ability with the willow was evident throughout his career. In red-ball cricket, Thorpe scored 6,744 runs at an average of 44.66, including 16 centuries and 39 half-centuries. In the ODIs, Thorpe featured in 82 matches, scoring 2,380 runs with a respectable average of 37.18.\n\nThorpe also took up the coaching role and guided England's top talent to remarkable victories across all formats of the game. ECB shared the news on Twitter.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport,\" read the statement.\n\nAlso read: ECB announces 14-member squad for home Tests against Sri Lanka\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game,\" the statement added.\n\nSurrey County Cricket Club, where Thorpe spent 17 years of his professional career, also mourned the loss of their great son.\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey, and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club, wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed,\" said Surrey chairman Oli Slipper.", "source": {"uri": "crictracker.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8259677665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:08:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:08:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:07:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://sportzwiki.com/cricket/graham-thorpe-former-england-cricketer-passes-away/", "title": "Graham Thorpe, Former England Cricketer, Passes Away", "body": "Graham Thorpe, former England batter and coach, has died at the age of 55, England and Wales Board confirmed on August 5, 2024. He had been battling a mysterious illness since 2022.\n\nGraham Thorpe played 100 Tests and 82 ODIs for England between 1993 and 2005, scoring 6744 and 2380 runs, respectively. He also scored 16 Test hundreds, with his top score of 200*. Graham Thorpe scored 21937 runs in 341 games of first-class cricket, including 49 hundreds and a best of 223*.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that the ECB shares the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game,\" ECB said in an official statement.\n\nHe captained England on three occasions and served in various coaching roles for his country between 2010 and 2022.\n\nGraham Thorpe made his first-class debut for Surrey in the summer of 1988 and established himself as a regular in 1989. He finally made his England debut at the age of 24, collecting 114 runs against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993.\n\nThorpe would go on to become a middle-order staple, with his undefeated double-hundred against New Zealand in Christchurch in 2002 standing out as one of his career highlights, with 28 fours and four sixes.\n\nOn the other hand, Oli Slipper, Chair at Surrey CCC said: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nThorpe made only a few appearances for England before retiring in 2005. He went on to start his coaching career in Australia, where he worked with Steve Smith and David Warner in New South Wales before joining the England and Wales Cricket Board as a batting coach.\n\nAfter leaving England, he was appointed Afghanistan's head coach in March 2022, but he did not accept the position due to illness.", "source": {"uri": "sportzwiki.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-08-444403083", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:35:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:35:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://srilankamirror.com/news/fonseka-amarasinghe-place-deposits-for-prez-polls/", "title": "Fonseka & Amarasinghe place deposits for Prez polls", "body": "Graham Thorpe, the former England and Surrey batter, has died aged 55, the ECB has announced.\n\nThorpe, who played 100 Tests for England between 1993 and 2005 and went on to work as batting coach for the senior men's team, was taken \"seriously ill\" in 2022, shortly after being named as Afghanistan's head coach.\n\nDuring his playing career, Thorpe scored 6744 Test runs, with 16 hundreds, and was also capped 82 times in one-day internationals. He played for Surrey between 1988 and 2005, scoring almost 20,000 runs for the county.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the ECB said in a statement. \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe joined the ECB in 2010 as lead batting coach, and was part of the backroom team that oversaw England's 2019 Men's World Cup success. He went on to work as assistant coach to Chris Silverwood, although he was among a number of the coaching staff to depart in the wake of the 2021-22 Ashes.\n\nHe had been due to take charge of Afghanistan, after being appointed in March 2022, but was unable to fulfil the role.\n\nAfter Thorpe was hospitalised in May of that year, England's newly appointed Test captain Ben Stokes wore a shirt with Thorpe's name and England cap number on the back for the toss at his first match in charge, against New Zealand at Lord's.\n\nOli Slipper, Surrey's chair said: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nGraham Thorpe, seen here with Joe Root, was part of England's 2019 World Cup-winning coaching staff*ICC via Getty Images\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, added: \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nA tough, counterattacking batter, Thorpe scored a century on debut against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993. He went on to become one England's premier Test batters during the 1990s and early 2000s, as well as a reliable one-day accumulator who featured at the 1996 and 1999 World Cups.\n\nHis career high point came during the winter of 2000-01, when hundreds in Lahore and Colombo helped England seal memorable series wins in Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Twelve months later, he scored an unbeaten double-hundred from just 231 balls to set up victory in Christchurch.\n\nHowever, after touring with England for 10 consecutive winters, the breakdown of Thorpe's marriage in 2002 led to him retiring from ODIs and taking an indefinite break from the game. He returned after more than a year out of the Test side to score a century against South Africa at The Oval, his home ground, and help secure a drawn series.\n\nHis final England appearance was the occasion of his 100th cap, against Bangladesh at Chester-le-Street, with the emergence of Kevin Pietersen leading to Thorpe being dropped for the 2005 Ashes.", "source": {"uri": "srilankamirror.com", {"uri": "8259647142", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:46:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:46:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:45:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/uk-sport-news/england-cricket-legend-graham-thorpe-29677341", "title": "England cricket legend Graham Thorpe dies aged 55 after serious illness", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nFormer England batter Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board has announced. Thorpe had been battling a serious illness since 2022.\n\nIn a statement, the ECB said: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\"\n\nThe ECB statement continued: \"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\"\n\nThe ECB added: \"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe represented Surrey for 17 years, and was a regular in the England test and white-ball teams. He won 100 test caps for his country, and played in the 1996 and 1999 World Cups, reports the Mirror.\n\nThorpe's former County team are now mourning his passing, with Surrey chairman Oli Slipper paying tribute to his legacy.\n\nSlipper remarked: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSurrey's CEO Steve Elworthy expressed his grief, saying: \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\"\n\nElworthy continued, offering condolences: \"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nAfter retiring from playing, Thorpe took up coaching, joining England's white ball team as batting coach in 2013 and later becoming assistant to boss Chris Silverwood in 2019.\n\nThorpe also had a stint as interim head coach for England's T20 series against Pakistan, securing a 2-1 victory, and stepped in during the fourth Test of the 2021/2022 Ashes series, managing to secure a draw in what was otherwise a challenging series for England.\n\nHe departed from his position at the conclusion of that series, and in March 2022, he was appointed as Afghanistans head coach. However, Thorpe tragically fell ill before he could begin the job.\n\nDuring a heartfelt tribute, England test captain Ben Stokes donned Thorpe's name and number in a match against New Zealand following his diagnosis.\n\nHis condition remains private as the Professional Cricketers' Association refrained from disclosing specifics, only stating in May 2022: \"Graham Thorpe has recently fallen seriously ill and is currently in hospital receiving treatment.\"\n\nThey added: \"His prognosis is unclear at this stage and we ask for privacy for him and his family at this time. Our thoughts are with Graham and his family.\"", "source": {"uri": "birminghammail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Birmingham Mail"}, "authors": [{"uri": "steve_wollaston@birminghammail.co.uk", {"uri": "8259727142", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:42:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:42:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:41:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://cricketaddictor.com/cricket-news/former-england-cricketer-graham-thorpe-passes-away-aged-55/", "title": "Former England Cricketer Graham Thorpe passes away aged 55", "body": "Graham Thorpe is one of the great sons of Surrey: Surrey Cricket Club\n\nFormer England batter and coach Graham Thorpe passed away at the age of 55. The England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) has confirmed the tragic news on Monday, August 5. Thorpe was known for his exceptional skills as a left-handed batter.\n\nWith a career spanning 13 years, Thorpe played 100 Test matches for England, scoring 6744 runs with the help of 16 centuries before retiring from the game in 2005. One of England's iconic figures, Thorpe, also featured in 83 ODIs, amassing 2380 runs, and had the honor of captaining the England cricket team on three occasions.\n\nIn addition to his playing career, Thorpe made significant contributions as a coach, serving in various roles for the England cricket team from 2010 to 2022. His death comes two years after he was reported to have fallen seriously ill and underwent treatment in a hospital in the UK.\n\nIn 2022, the Players Cricket Association (PCA) released a statement on behalf of Thorpe's family and said that the former left-handed batter had \"fallen seriously ill\" at the time and was in the hospital to receive treatment. The PCA also revealed that \"Thorpe's prognosis is unclear at this stage.\".\n\nMeanwhile, the ECB expressed deep sorrow on the demise of Thorpe while hailing his legacy as one of the finest players of his generation and his impactful coaching career with the England team.\n\nThe ECB said in an official statement: \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\nLater, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe was also a standout performer at the county level, amassing 21,937 runs for Surrey in First-Class cricket. He made 49 centuries at an impressive average of 45.04. He has also 10871 runs in List-A cricket in 354 matches to his name. Meanwhile, the Chair of Surrey Cricket Club, Oli Slipper, also paid tribute to Thorpe by hailing him as one of the great sons of Surrey.\n\nOli Slipper said in a statement: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey, and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the club as a cricketer and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"", "source": {"uri": "cricketaddictor.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022. Thorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. {"uri": "8259975949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:20:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:20:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:19:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/sport/12110444/graham-thorpe-dead-england-cricket/", "title": "England cricket legend Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Thorpe leaves behind his wife Amanda and their four children\n\nENGLAND cricket legend Graham Thorpe has died aged 55.\n\nThorpe captained his country during a long and illustrious career for England and Surrey.\n\nThe cricketer had fallen seriously ill in 2022, his family said at the time.\n\nThorpe made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nThorpe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nIn a statement, the England and Wales Cricket Board said: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\n\n\"We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nFormer England captain Michael Vaughan led tributes to his former team-mate.\n\nVaughan said: \"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate.\n\n\"You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend.\"\n\nPosting on Twitter, Vaughan added: \"Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game as a coach after his retirement from playing.\n\nHe moved to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe later returned to work as a coach with England between 2010 and 2022.\n\nThorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus.\n\nHe secured a nail-biting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing.\n\n\"He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to.\n\n\"We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nThe Professional Cricketers' Association shared a statement on behalf of Thorpe's family in May 2022, saying the England legend had \"fallen seriously ill\" and was in hospital receiving treatment.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage... our thoughts are with Graham and his family,\" the statement read.\n\nHe is survived by his wife Amanda and four children, Henry, Amelia, Kitty and Emma.\n\nThorpe was born on August 1, 1969 in the market town of Farnham, little more than an hour from The Oval.\n\nHe remembered being drafted by local side Wrecclesham's Under-17s while still only eight years old.\n\nThorpe was spotted early by Surrey, who picked him up as an under-11.\n\nSurrey never let him go, even when Brentford Football Club came calling with the offer of trials.\n\nThorpe showed enough football promise to be selected by England Schools as a ball-playing link between defence and midfield.\n\nBut he would go on to choose the summer sport and later became one of the country's most accomplished players of spin.", "source": {"uri": "the-sun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The US Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "harry_goodwin@the-sun.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-08-444194985", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:26:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:26:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:23:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/cricket/graham-thorpe-england-cricketer-dies-3209177", "title": "Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Thorpe won 100 Test caps during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation\n\nFormer England cricketer Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55.\n\nThorpe won 100 Test caps during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation.\n\nHe also enjoyed a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey before going on to coach for the national team.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the England and Wales Cricket Board announced on Monday.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his team-mates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259635392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": true, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:38:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:38:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:37:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/uk-sports/2024/08/05/former-england-and-surrey-batter-graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55/", "title": "Former England and Surrey batter Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Former England batter Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55.\n\nThorpe made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nThorpe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nA statement from the England and Wales Cricket Board read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022. Thorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nMichael Vaughan, who captained Thorpe towards the end of his Test career, wrote on X: \"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.\"\n\nCurrent England opener Ben Duckett also wrote on X, saying: \"Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him.\n\n\"My thoughts go out to all of his friends and family during this tough time.\"", "source": {"uri": "expressandstar.com", Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Former England and Surrey batter Graham Thorpe dies aged 55\n\nPA Sport Staff\n\n5 August 2024 at 9:36 am\n\nFormer England batter Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55.\n\nThorpe made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nThorpe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nA statement from the England and Wales Cricket Board read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022. Thorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nMichael Vaughan, who captained Thorpe towards the end of his Test career, wrote on X: \"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.\"\n\nCurrent England opener Ben Duckett also wrote on X, saying: \"Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him.\n\n\"My thoughts go out to all of his friends and family during this tough time.\"", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nTwo years ago, the PCA released a statement on behalf of Thorpe's family, saying he had \"recently fallen seriously ill\" and was in hospital to receive treatment, adding that \"his prognosis is unclear at this stage.\"\n\nThorpe played exactly 100 Tests for England and scored 16 centuries, retiring in {"uri": "8259775698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:14:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:14:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:13:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://gulfnews.com/sport/cricket/former-england-batsman-graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55-1.1722847864785", "title": "Former England batsman Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "London: Former England batsman and coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced on Monday.\n\nThorpe won 100 Test caps between 1993 and 2005 and scored 16 centuries during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation.\n\nIn total he scored 6,744 Test runs for England at an average of 44.66 and also appeared in 82 one-day internationals.\n\nread more Former England batter Graham Thorpe in hospital after falling 'seriously ill' Afghanistan Cricket Board names Graham Thorpe as team's new head coach\n\nAlongside his international exploits he enjoyed a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey.\n\nAfter retiring in 2005, he transitioned into coaching, working with the England international teams in various roles between 2010 and 2022.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said in a statement.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\nAfter leaving his role with England following defeat to Australia in the 2021-2022 Ashes series, Thorpe was appointed head coach of Afghanistan.\n\nHowever, he did not take up the role after the Professional Cricketers' Association revealed in May 2022 Thorpe had fallen seriously ill with an unclear diagnosis.\n\nTributes from stars past and present have poured in for a player that was often a shining light during a difficult time for the England Test side during the 1990s.\n\nThorpe scored 114 on his debut against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993 and would go on to become a mainstay of the middle-order making a highest Test score of 200 not out against New Zealand in 2002.\n\n\"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate,\" former England captain Michael Vaughan posted on X.\n\n\"You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend.\"\n\nCurrent England skipper Ben Stokes posted a photo of him wearing a jersey emblazoned with \"Thorpe 564\", the latter's Test cap number, with a series of heart emojis.\n\nThorpe spent the entirety of his playing career at Surrey and chair Oli Slipper said the country had lost one of its \"great sons\".\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again,\" Slipper said in a Surrey statement.\n\n\"He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nMore From Cricket Vandersay spins {"uri": "2024-08-444295514", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:05:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:05:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:03:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.india.com/cricket-2/shocking-former-england-batter-graham-thorpe-dies-at-the-age-of-55-ecb-and-anil-kumble-among-those-who-offer-condolences-7141065/", "title": "SHOCKING! Former England Batter Graham Thorpe Dies At The Age Of 55", "body": "Former England batter Graham Thorpe, who celebrated his 55th birthday just a few days back on August 1, died at the age of 55. The England & Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced the shocking news o\n\nFormer England batter Graham Thorpe, who celebrated his 55th birthday just a few days back on August 1, died at the age of 55. The England & Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced the shocking news on social media platform 'X' on Tuesday (August 5).\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB statement read.\n\nThorpe turned out in 100 Tests and 82 ODIs in his international career spanning 12 years. The Surrey and England left-handed batter notched up 6,744 runs at an average of 44.66 with 16 Test tons and 39 fifties. In ODI cricket, Thorpe scored 2,380 runs at an average of 37.18 with 21 fifties to his name.\n\nFormer India captain and head coach Anil Kumble also offered his condolences after hearing about the death of Thorpe. \"Sad to hear about Graham Thorpe. He was a gritty and a fantastic batter who was always ready for a battle on the pitch. Heartfelt condolences to his friends and family,\" Kumble wrote on 'X'.\n\nThe former England southpaw was set to join as the Afghanistan head coach but was taken 'seriously ill' in 2022. \"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game,\" the ECB statement read.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.,\" the statement added.\n\nThorpe had joined the ECB setup in 2010 as batting coach worked as assistant coach to Chris Silverwood with England men's team. He was among a number of the team management to depart in the wake of the 2021-22 Ashes. After Thorpe was hospitalised in May, England's newly-appointed Test captain Ben Stokes wore a shirt with Thorpe's name and England cap number on the back for the toss at his first match in charge, {"uri": "8259644151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:44:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:44:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:43:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.wisden.com/cricket-news/graham-thorpe-one-of-englands-greatest-batters-dies-aged-55", "title": "Graham Thorpe, One Of England's Greatest Batters, Dies Aged 55 | England Cricket News", "body": "Former English batter Graham Thorpe passed away on Monday (August 5), at the age of 55.\n\nA statement released by the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) on Monday read: ''It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.''\n\nThorpe played 100 Test matches and 82 ODIs for England, scoring over 9000 runs in international cricket and leading the team on three occasions. In 1997, he was named as Wisden's Cricketer of the Year, and in 2002 recorded his first and only double century in Test cricket against New Zealand.\n\nHe also represented Surrey in 189 first-class matches, notching up over 12,000 runs. After retirement, Thorpe took up various coaching positions with New South Wales, Surrey and the England national team. In March 2022, he was announced as Afghanistan's head coach but fell seriously ill with an \"unclear prognosis\" in May that same year, before he could begin the role.\n\nThe Professional Cricketers Association (PCA) announced his illness at the time on behalf of his family. Thorpe's passing is thought to be related to this illness, but the exact cause remains unconfirmed at this point.", "source": {"uri": "wisden.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Wisden"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-08-444218124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:50:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:50:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:36:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/former-england-surrey-batter-graham-073216148.html", "title": "Former England and Surrey batter Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Former England and Surrey batter Graham Thorpe dies aged 55\n\nPA Sport Staff\n\n5 August 2024 at 9:36 am\n\nFormer England batter Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55.\n\nThorpe made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nThorpe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nA statement from the England and Wales Cricket Board read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022. Thorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nMichael Vaughan, who captained Thorpe towards the end of his Test career, wrote on X: \"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.\"\n\nCurrent England opener Ben Duckett also wrote on X, saying: \"Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him.\n\n\"My thoughts go out to all of his friends and family during this tough time.\"", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "8259718847", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:36:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:36:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:36:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/cricket/graham-thorpe-health-battle-death-33394564", "title": "Graham Thorpe's health battle was made clear before tragic death aged just 55", "body": "Former England cricket star Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, with tributes pouring in from former team-mates and plenty of others across the sporting world\n\nFormer England cricketer Graham Thorpe was taken 'seriously ill' just two years before his tragic death at the age of 55.\n\nThorpe played 100 Tests during a memorable career, scoring a fantastic double century against New Zealand in 2002. He spent his county cricket career with Surrey, representing his home county for more than a decade and a half, and also worked as a coach and broadcaster.\n\nBack in 2022, when Thorpe was hospitalised, the Professional Cricketers' Association issued a statement on his health at the request of the player's family..\"Graham Thorpe has recently fallen seriously ill and is currently in hospital receiving treatment,\" it read.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage and we ask for privacy for him and his family at this time. Our thoughts are with Graham and his family.\"\n\nTributes have flooded in for the popular batsman, who had been due to take over as Afghanistan coach in 2022 before falling ill. Plenty of those from Surrey CCC have honoured Thorpe, as have former team-mates.\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again,\" Surrey CCC chair Oli Slipper said. \"He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nShare your own tributes to Graham Thorpe in the comments section\n\n\"It is with great sadness that the ECB shares the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" an ECB statement read following Thorpe's passing. \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\nThe cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nEngland captain Ben Stokes and former skipper Michael Vaughan were among the players to post tributes. \"RIP Thorpey .. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career,\" Vaughan wrote.\n\n\"You were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend ... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family.\"", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tom_victor@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Tom {"uri": "8259703472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:25:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:25:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:24:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55-33394749", "title": "Graham Thorpe dies aged 55 as tributes paid to former England cricket legend", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nFormer England cricketer Graham Thorpe has died aged 55.\n\nThe England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced the batter's death after he battled with a serious illness for two years.\n\nIn a statement, the ECB said: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThe Mirror reports that he spent 17 years playing for Surrey - earning a regular place in the England Test and ODI teams. He earned 100 Test caps for his country, as well as playing in the 1996 and 1999 World Cups.\n\nThorpe struck Over 6,700 Test runs at an average of almost 45, including 16 centuries. His former county is also mourning their loss, with Surrey chairman Oli Slipper hailing his legacy.\n\nSlipper said: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey's CEO, added: \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans. Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nThorpe went on to become a coach. He joined the England white ball coaching staff as batting coach in 2013, before being promoted to becoming boss Chris Silverwood's assistant in 2019.\n\nHe was named interim head coach for England's T20 series against Pakistan and led his country to a 2-1 win. He also stood in for the fourth Test of the 2021/2022 Ashes series, claiming a draw, the only game England did not lose.\n\nHe left his role at the end of that series, before being named head coach of Afghanistan in March 2022. Sadly, he would never take up that role after falling seriously ill. England test captain Ben Stokes wore Thorpe's name and number ahead of a match against New Zealand as a tribute following that diagnosis.\n\nThe exact nature of his illness is unknown, with the Professional Cricketers' Association saying at the time of his diagnosis: In a May 2022 statement, the PCA said: \"Graham Thorpe has recently fallen seriously ill and is currently in hospital receiving treatment.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage and we ask for privacy for him and his family at this time. Our thoughts are with Graham and his family.\"\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond - Sign up to our daily newsletter here.", "source": {"uri": "dailyrecord.co.uk", {"uri": "8259986073", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:26:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:26:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:25:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.adaderana.lk/sportsnews.php?nid=10566", "title": "Former England batter Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Former England and Surrey batter Graham Thorpe has died aged 55, it has been announced.\n\nThorpe played 100 Tests for England between 1993 and 2005, as well as 82 one-day internationals.\n\nA stylish left-handed batter, he scored 6,744 Test runs for England, including 16 centuries, at an average of 44.66.\n\nCurrent England captain Ben Stokes was among those to pay tribute to Thorpe, along with the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) and Surrey, while Michael Vaughan said his former team-mate was a \"legend\" who had \"gone far too young\".\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said in a statement.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his team-mates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\n\n\"We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe spent his entire first-class playing career at Surrey, whom he represented from 1988 to 2005.\n\nSurrey chair Oli Slipper said Thorpe \"is one of the great sons\" of the county and \"there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again\".\n\nSurrey chief executive Steve Elworthy added: \"He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\"\n\nThorpe scored an unbeaten 114 in the second innings of his Test debut against Australia in 1993 and had a Test best of 200 not out, made against New Zealand in 2002.\n\nHe began coaching in Australia after retiring from playing in 2005, working with New South Wales before joining the England set-up from 2010 to 2022.\n\nThorpe was appointed head coach of Afghanistan in March 2022, but he was admitted to hospital with a serious illness before he could join the team.\n\nBBC cricket correspondent Jonathan Agnew said Thorpe was a \"mainstay of England's middle order throughout the 1990s\" and called him \"a gritty and unfussy left-hander\".\n\nAgnew added that, after it had been announced that Thorpe had been admitted to hospital in a serious condition, \"no details were given and there have been no public updates until today\".\n\nThe cause of Thorpe's death has not been announced.\n\n'Great man and legend'\n\nEngland captain Stokes wore a special shirt in support of Thorpe in June 2022 after the Professional Cricketers' Association said the ex-England batter was \"seriously ill\".\n\nThe shirt had Thorpe's name and the number 564 on the back - signifying his status as the 564th player to be capped by England.\n\nStokes donned the shirt at the toss for the first Test against New Zealand at Lord's.\n\nHe posted a picture on social media of himself in the shirt on Monday, along with a series of heart emojis following the news about Thorpe's death.\n\nEx-England skipper Vaughan thanked Thorpe \"for all the advice throughout my career\".\n\nVaughan added: \"You were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend.\"\n\nCurrent England opener Ben Duckett said Thorpe's death was \"heartbreaking\".\n\nDuckett added on X: \"He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him. My thoughts go out to all of his friends and family during this tough time.\"\n\nFormer Sri Lanka captain Kumar Sangakkara described Thorpe as a \"great man and legend\" as he paid tribute to his fellow left-hander.\n\nThorpe was a Wisden Cricketer of the Year winner in 1997 and the sport's 'bible' described him as \"one of England's greatest batters\" in a post on social media.\n\nFormer England spinner Shaun Udal said: \"Such tragic news about Graham Thorpe, played with and against the little legend since the age of 10, great player and human being.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8259685553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:13:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:13:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:13:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://thecurrent.pk/former-england-batsman-graham-thorpe-passes-away/", "title": "Former England batsman Graham Thorpe passes away", "body": "Former England cricketer and coach Graham Thorpe, known as one of the best Test batsmen of his time, has died at the age of 55 from an illness that he had been suffering from since time.\n\nThe England Cricket Board (ECB) has confirmed his death, saying, \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\"\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans worldwide. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to incredible victories across all game formats.\"\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nIn 2002, Thorpe took a break from cricket to deal with his first marriage falling apart. The media humiliation and being separated from his two children caused a \"total breakdown.\" However, after a 13-month break, he returned to the Test team in 2003 with a brilliant century against South Africa at the Oval. The following year was the best of his career, with an average of 73.15 in 20 Test innings in 2004, all while batting at No. 5.\n\nThorpe was a skilled left-handed batter and a right-handed bowler. In his 12-year international career, he played exactly 100 Test matches and 82 ODIs. He also played 189 first-class matches for Surrey, scoring 49 centuries and averaging 45.04 runs before retiring in 2005.", "source": {"uri": "thecurrent.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\"\n\nIf further added, \"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today.\"\n\nThe left-handed batsman and right-hander bowler, Thorpe during his 12 years of international career played 100 tests and 82 one-day internationals.\n\nThe ECB extended its condolences to 'his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends,' and said that Thorpe will be always remembered for his 'extraordinary contributions' {"uri": "2024-08-444292511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:03:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:03:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:28:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/graham-thorpe-renowned-england-cricket-player-and-ex-coach-passed-away-at-55-michael-vaughan-and-ben-stokes-honor-the-100-test-batsman-who-achieved-16-centuries-in-his-12-year-career/", "title": "Graham Thorpe, renowned England cricket player and ex-coach, passed away at 55. Michael Vaughan and Ben Stokes honor the 100-Test batsman who achieved 16 centuries in his 12-year career. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Legendary England cricketer Graham Thorpe has died aged 55, with Michael Vaughan and Ben Stokes leading tributes to the former batter.\n\nThorpe made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nHe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nThorpe is survived by his second wife Amanda, whom he married in 2007, and four children, Henry, Amelia, Kitty and Emma. He separated from first wife Nicola in 2002.\n\nVaughan, who captained Thorpe towards the end of his Test career, wrote on X: 'RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.'\n\nAnd Stokes tweeted five love heart emojis next to a picture of Thorpe with 564 on his shirt, denoting his Test cap number.\n\nCurrent England opener Ben Duckett wrote on X: 'Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him. My thoughts go out to all of his friends and family during this tough time.'\n\nA statement from the England and Wales Cricket Board read: 'It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n'There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n'More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n'His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n'Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n'The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.'\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022.\n\nThorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said: 'Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n'Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.'\n\nThorpe's former county Surrey also described him as one of their 'great sons'.\n\nChair Oli Slipper said: 'He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n'He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.'\n\nDuring his playing career, Thorpe averaged an impressive 44.7 runs in Test matches.\n\nHis highest score was 200 not out and the talented middle-order batsmen also played 77 One Day Internationals.\n\nOne of his most memorable Test innings came in 2000 against Pakistan in Karachi. After a final day implosion from the hosts, Thorpe produced an unbeaten 64 in near darkness towards the end of his innings to lead England to their first series win in Pakistan for 39 years, and Pakistan's first loss at the National Stadium in 35 years.\n\n'I think literally five to ten minutes after we came off, it was pitch black,' Thorpe told Cricket Monthly. 'From the dressing room, coming back on to the balcony, it was pitch black.\n\n'We opened up bottles of lemonade, because we couldn't drink in Pakistan. We were on a flight back to Dubai that evening, where we did have a few Guinnesses. There was about a two-hour turnaround from the end of the game, back to the hotel and on to a flight that night.'\n\nThorpe racked up more than 2,000 runs in the shorter format of the game and his intelligence and leadership allowed a smooth transition into coaching when he retired from playing in 2006.\n\nHe went on to begin a coaching career in Australia, where he worked with the likes of Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales, before joining the England and Wales Cricket Board as a batting coach.\n\nHe worked as assistant with the senior side under Trevor Bayliss and Chris Silverwood, stepping up to lead the team in this winter's Sydney Test against Australia due to Silverwood's coronavirus diagnosis.\n\nHis position as England assistant coach looked untenable after the conclusion of the Ashes , when police were called to the team hotel in Hobart while he was smoking a cigar during a rooftop drinking session inside the premises that lasted until 6am.\n\nIt was an unfortunate ending to Thorpe's role in the England coaching set-up and he is still held in enormously high regard among players and fans.\n\nIn May, the Professional Cricketers' Association revealed Thorpe had fallen seriously ill with an unclear diagnosis. His cause of death has not yet been revealed.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259644279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:44:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:44:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:44:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.hamhigh.co.uk/news/national/uk-today/24497047.former-england-cricket-player-graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55/", "title": "Former England batter Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "The England and Wales Cricket Board has announced the death of former England batter Graham Thorpe MBE at the age of 55.\n\nThorpe won 100 Test caps during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation with his international exploits running alongside a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the ECB said.\n\nIt added: \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his team-mates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nDuring an era of English cricket that is most often remembered for its lean years, Graham Thorpe established himself as a player with the class and calibre to stand above the crowd.\n\nMost England fans might happily forget the 90s entirely were it not for the emergence of Thorpe who burst onto the scene in 1993 with an Ashes century on Test debut and bowed out with a hundred caps to his name 12 years later.\n\nSuch longevity was an achievement in itself at a time when team selection often appeared to be determined by lucky dip and the left-hander played a variety of roles during his time at the top.\n\nRunning the gamut from stylish newcomer to grizzled veteran Thorpe proved himself a dependably elite performer in an environment where chaos and collapse never seemed far away.", "source": {"uri": "hamhigh.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Ham & High"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259652283", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:50:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:50:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:49:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://kalingatv.com/sports/former-england-cricketer-graham-thorpe-passes-away-at-the-age-of-55/", "title": "Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe passes away at the age of 55", "body": "Former cricketer from England, Graham Thorpe passed away at the age of 55 years. The news of him passing away was confirmed by England and Wales Cricket Board.\n\nIn a short statement the Board mentioned, \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\"\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game,\" the statement further read.\n\nEarlier, nearly two years back, the PCA released a statement on behalf of his family, revealing that Graham Thorpe had fallen seriously ill and was in hospital to receive treatment.\n\nIt is worth mentioning here that Thorpe played exactly 100 Tests for England and scored 16 centuries, retiring in 2005. He used to be number four or five batsman and his first Test century came against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993, while the last was against South Africa in Durban, in 2004.\n\nGraham Thorpe
