{"uri": "2024-08-444357367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:57:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:57:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:53:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/29687859/graham-thorpe-wife-amanda-england/", "title": "Graham Thorpe's wife Amanda stopped life's struggles 'eating away at him'", "body": "GRAHAM Thorpe's wife Amanda helped give the England legend stability and stop matters off the field from \"eating away at him\".\n\nCricket icon Thorpe, who played for England in 100 Test Matches and 82 One Day International games, has died at age 55 following a serious health battle.\n\nEx-England international cricketer Mike Atherton once said that, of all the athletes he played with, Thorpe was the one \"whose state of mind most affected his play\".\n\nHe added: \"A happy, contented Graham Thorpe is a world-class player, his presence beneficial to any team.\n\n\"If something off the field is eating away at him, he cannot put it to the back of his mind and concentrate on his cricket.\"\n\nThorpe's second wife Amanda would help provide the stability he needed to continue excelling in the sport.\n\nThe celebrated batsman made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nThorpe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nA statement from the England and Wales Cricket Board read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022.\n\nThorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nThe Professional Cricketers' Association shared a statement on behalf of Thorpe's family in May 2022, saying the England legend had \"fallen seriously ill\" and was in hospital receiving treatment.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage... our thoughts are with Graham and his family,\" the {"uri": "8259850135", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:02:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:02:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:01:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/graham-thorpes-health-battle-revealed-33395760", "title": "Graham Thorpe's health battle revealed two years before sad death", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nFormer England cricketer Graham Thorpe was taken 'seriously ill' just two years before his tragic death at the age of 55.\n\nThorpe played 100 Tests during a memorable career, scoring a fantastic double century against New Zealand in 2002. He spent his county cricket career with Surrey, representing his home county for more than a decade and a half, and also worked as a coach and broadcaster.\n\nBack in 2022, when Thorpe was hospitalised, the Professional Cricketers' Association issued a statement on his health at the request of the player's family.\n\n\"Graham Thorpe has recently fallen seriously ill and is currently in hospital receiving treatment,\" it read.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage and we ask for privacy for him and his family at this time. Our thoughts are with Graham and his family.\"\n\nTributes have flooded in for the popular batsman, who had been due to take over as Afghanistan coach in 2022 before falling ill. Plenty of those from Surrey CCC have honoured Thorpe, as have former team-mates, the Mirror reports.\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again,\" Surrey CCC chair Oli Slipper said. \"He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\"\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\n\"It is with great sadness that the ECB shares the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" an ECB statement read following Thorpe's passing. \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nEngland captain Ben Stokes and former skipper Michael Vaughan were among the players to post tributes. \"RIP Thorpey .. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career,\" Vaughan wrote.\n\n\"You were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend ... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family.\"\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the\n\ndeep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" England and Wales Cricket Board said on X.\n\nThorpe played exactly 100 Tests from 1993 to 2005, scoring 6744 runs -- including 16 centuries, at an average of 44.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world,\" ECB added.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rediff.com India Ltd."}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graham_Thorpe", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Graham Thorpe"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England_and_Wales_Cricket_Board", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "England and Wales Cricket Board"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_cricket", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Test cricket"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England_cricket_team", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "England cricket team"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Order of the British Empire"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrey_County_Cricket_Club", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Surrey County Cricket Club"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cricket", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Cricket"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "England"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "England"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Cricket", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Cricket", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Cricket/Movies", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Cricket/Movies", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Cricket/History", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Cricket/History", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 83}], "image": "https://im.rediff.com/cricket/2024/aug/05thorpe.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9790854", "eventUri": "eng-9790854", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3333333333333333, "wgt": 209, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8259837989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:54:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:54:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:53:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13709741/Graham-Thorpe-ex-England-cricketer-coach-dies-aged-55.html", "title": "Graham Thorpe, ex-England cricketer and coach, dies aged 55", "body": "Legendary England cricketer Graham Thorpe has died aged 55, with Michael Vaughan and Ben Stokes leading tributes to the former batter. Thorpe made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nHe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey. His final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nThorpe is survived by his second wife Amanda, whom he married in 2007, and four children, Henry, Amelia, Kitty and Emma. He separated from first wife Nicola in 2002. He came from a family of cricketers, with his father Geoff being the former chairman of Farnham Cricket Club and brother Ian captaining the 2nd XI for many years, with mother Toni the long-serving scorer. His other brother Alan also played for Farnham. Vaughan, who captained Thorpe towards the end of his Test career, wrote on X: 'RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.'\n\nAnd Stokes tweeted five love heart emojis next to a picture of Thorpe with 564 on his shirt, denoting his Test cap number. Current England opener Ben Duckett wrote on X: 'Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him. My thoughts go out to all of his friends and family during this tough time.' A statement from the England and Wales Cricket Board read: 'It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n'There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. 'More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. 'His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. 'Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. 'The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.'\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner. He returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022. Thorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said: 'Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans. 'Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.' Thorpe's former county Surrey also described him as one of their 'great sons'. Chair Oli Slipper said: 'He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. 'He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.'\n\nDuring his playing career, Thorpe averaged an impressive 44.7 runs in Test matches. His highest score was 200 not out and the talented middle-order batsmen also played 77 One Day Internationals. One of his most memorable Test innings came in 2000 against Pakistan in Karachi. After a final day implosion from the hosts, Thorpe produced an unbeaten 64 in near darkness towards the end of his innings to lead England to their first series win in Pakistan for 39 years, and Pakistan's first loss at the National Stadium in 35 years. 'I think literally five to ten minutes after we came off, it was pitch black,' Thorpe told Cricket Monthly. 'From the dressing room, coming back on to the balcony, it was pitch black. 'We opened up bottles of lemonade, because we couldn't drink in Pakistan. We were on a flight back to Dubai that evening, where we did have a few Guinnesses. There was about a two-hour turnaround from the end of the game, back to the hotel and on to a flight that night.'\n\nThorpe racked up more than 2,000 runs in the shorter format of the game and his intelligence and leadership allowed a smooth transition into coaching when he retired from playing in 2006. He went on to begin a coaching career in Australia, where he worked with the likes of Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales, before joining the England and Wales Cricket Board as a batting coach. He worked as assistant with the senior side under Trevor Bayliss and Chris Silverwood, stepping up to lead the team in this winter's Sydney Test against Australia due to Silverwood's coronavirus diagnosis.\n\nHis position as England assistant coach looked untenable after the conclusion of the Ashes , when police were called to the team hotel in Hobart while he was smoking a cigar during a rooftop drinking session inside the premises that lasted until 6am. It was an unfortunate ending to Thorpe's role in the England coaching set-up and he is still held in enormously high regard among players and fans. In May, the Professional Cricketers' Association revealed Thorpe had fallen seriously ill with an unclear diagnosis. His cause of death has not yet been revealed.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? {"uri": "2024-08-444348688", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:51:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:51:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:44:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.cityam.com/english-cricket-mourns-beloved-batter-and-coach-thorpe-after-he-dies-aged-55/", "title": "Graham Thorpe: England batter and coach dies, aged 55", "body": "English cricket is mourning the passing of one of its best-loved figures after Graham Thorpe died, aged just 55.\n\nThorpe scored more than 9,000 runs for England in 100 Tests and 82 one-day internationals as well as starring for Surrey at county level.\n\nAfter retiring in 2005 he went into coaching with New South Wales, Surrey and England and was due to take up the post of Afghanistan head coach before falling ill in 2022.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the England and Wales Cricket Board said.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\n\n\"We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nFormer England captain Michael Vaughan, a former international teammate of Thorpe, said: \"RIP Thorpey. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend.\"\n\nCurrent England open Ben Duckett called the news \"heartbreaking\", adding: \"He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him.\"\n\nSurrey chief executive Steve Elworthy said: \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. He was also capped 82 times in one-day internationals for 2,380 runs.\n\nThorpe later became a batting coach and assistant coach of the England men's team under Chris Silverwood.\n\n''The cricket world is in mourning today. New to Kayo? Start your free trial today >\n\nHe also played 341 first-class matches, scoring 21,937 runs including 49 centuries as well as 354 domestic one-day matches with over 10,871 runs in an incredible career.\n\nAfter his playing career, Thorpe held several coaching roles for England between 2010 and 2022.\n\nIn March 2022, Thorpe was announced as the new head coach of Afghanistan but was unable to take up the role after falling seriously ill and being hospitalised for treatment.\n\nThe cricket world was quick to pay tribute.\n\nThe England and Wales Cricket Board released a statement announcing the news.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the statement read.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nEnglish county club Surrey, the club he played his entire county career, also remembered Thorpe as a \"legend\".\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions,\" Surrey Cricket Club chair Oli Slipper said.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nEngland supporters club The Barmy Army posted simply: \"Tragic news. {"uri": "8259697616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:21:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:21:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:20:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/29683664/graham-thorpe-family-difficult-time/", "title": "Graham Thorpe's family enduring 'incredibly difficult time' after tragic death", "body": "GRAHAM Thorpe's heartbroken family are enduring an \"incredibly difficult time\" following the cricket legend's death at just 55.\n\nThorpe, who played for England in 100 Test Matches and 82 One Day International games, has passed away following a serious health battle.\n\nThe batter made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nThorpe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nA statement from the England and Wales Cricket Board read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022.\n\nThorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nThe Professional Cricketers' Association shared a statement on behalf of Thorpe's family in May 2022, saying the England legend had \"fallen seriously ill\" and was in hospital receiving treatment.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage... our thoughts are with Graham and his family,\" the statement read.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "henry_martin@thesun.co.uk", "name": "Henry Martin", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8259683303", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:13:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:13:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:11:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.news18.com/cricket/former-england-batter-graham-thorpe-passes-away-8990511.html", "title": "England Batting Legend Graham Thorpe Passes Away At 55 - News18", "body": "After making his international debut in May 1993, Thorpe scored 6744 runs in 100 Tests and 2380 runs in 82 ODIs for England during his 12-year-long career.\n\nFormer England batter Graham Thorpe, who played in 100 Tests and 82 ODIs for the Three Lions during his 12-year-long international career, passed away at the age of 55 on Monday, August 5.\n\nThe England and Wales Cricket Board took to X (formerly Twitter) to confirm the news of the former left-handed middle-order batter's demise.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said in a statement.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe made his international debut for England against Australia in Manchester on May 19, 1993. His first red-ball match for the Poms was also against the Aussies in Nottingham on July 1 during the 1993 Ashes series. He scored a century (114*) in the second innings of his debut match as a No. 7 batter.\n\nDuring his 12-year-long Test career, Thorpe amassed a total of 6744 runs for the English team. His career-best score was 200 runs, which he made against New Zealand during a Test match played in Christchurch from March 14 to 18 in 2002.\n\nIn ODIs, Thorpe scored 2380 runs in 77 innings of 82 matches. He finished his career with 21 half-centuries for England in the 50-over format of the game and also picked up two wickets. He represented England in the 1996 and 1999 ODI World Cups as well.\n\nAfter his retirement Thorpe also served as the batting coach of England's senior men's team.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", {"uri": "8259771352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:10:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:10:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:10:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/sport/cricket/article/3273256/no-appropriate-words-after-former-england-batsman-coach-graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55", "title": "'No appropriate words' after Former England batsman Graham Thorpe dies, aged 55", "body": "One of the best batsman of his generation, Thorpe earned 100 Test caps between 1993 and 2005, scoring 16 centuries\n\nFormer England batsman and coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) said on Monday.\n\nThorpe won 100 Test caps between 1993 and 2005 and scored 16 centuries during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batsman of his generation.\n\nIn total he scored 6,744 Test runs for England at an average of 44.66 and also appeared in 82 one-day internationals.\n\nAlongside his international exploits he enjoyed a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey.\n\nAfter retiring in 2005, he transitioned into coaching, working with the England international teams in various roles between 2010 and 2022.\n\n\u201cThere seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham\u2019s death,\u201d the ECB said in a statement. \u201cMore than one of England\u2019s finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\u201cHis skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\u201cLater, as a coach, he guided the best England men\u2019s talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\u201d\n\nAfter leaving his role with England following defeat to Australia in the 2021-2022 Ashes series, Thorpe was appointed head coach of Afghanistan.\n\nHowever, he did not take up the role after the Professional Cricketers\u2019 Association revealed in May 2022 Thorpe had fallen seriously ill with an unclear diagnosis.\n\nTributes from stars past and present have poured in for a player that was often a shining light during a difficult time for the England Test side during the 1990s.\n\nThorpe scored 114 on his debut against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993 and would go on to become a mainstay of the middle-order making a highest Test score of 200 not out against New Zealand in 2002.\n\n\u201cRIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant teammate,\u201d former England captain Michael Vaughan posted on X.\n\n\u201cYou have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend.\u201d\n\nCurrent England skipper Ben Stokes posted a photo of him wearing a jersey emblazoned with \u201cThorpe 564\u201d, the latter\u2019s Test cap number, with a series of heart emojis.\n\nThorpe spent the entirety of his playing career at Surrey and chair Oli Slipper said the country had lost one of its \u201cgreat sons\u201d.\n\n\u201cGraham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again,\u201d Slipper said.\n\n\u201cHe is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\u201cHe made outstanding contributions to the club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\u201d", "source": He also played 82 one-day internationals and more than 341 first-class matches scoring 21,000 runs.\n\nIn a statement, The England and Wales Cricket Board said: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Urgent Cobra meeting to be held after weekend of rioting and disorder across UK\n\n''More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.''\n\nOli Slipper, Chair at his home county of Surry where he played all his career, said: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again.\n\n\"He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, the club's CEO, added \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nAfter his playing career, Thorpe also served on England's coaching team He had been appointed as the new {"uri": "8259733498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:46:21", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:46:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:45:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://7news.com.au/sport/cricket/cricket-world-in-mourning-after-shock-death-of-england-great-graham-thorpe-aged-55-c-15598975", "title": "Cricket world in mourning after legend's shock death, aged 55", "body": "Former England batter Graham Thorpe has died at the age of just 55.\n\nThe England and Wales Cricket Board confirmed the shock news on Monday.\n\nThorpe won 100 Test caps during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation, with his international exploits running alongside a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey.\n\nHe also later went into coaching, including spending time with the New South Wales state side and England's national team.\n\nIn Mach 2022 he was appointed coach of Afghanistan but fell seriously ill before beginning his role.\n\nTributes quickly came flowing in for the cricket great.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the ECB said.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nHe was an England regular, scoring 16 Test centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022. Thorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nMichael Vaughan, who captained Thorpe towards the end of his Test career, wrote on social media platform X: \"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant teammate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend ... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.\"\n\nCurrent England opener Ben Duckett also wrote on X, saying: \"Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him.\n\n\"My thoughts go out to all of his friends and family during this tough time.\"", "source": {"uri": "7news.com.au", {"uri": "8259635062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:38:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:38:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:37:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/cricket/news/12123/13191069/former-england-batter-thorpe-dies-aged-55", "title": "Graham Thorpe: Former England and Surrey batter dies aged 55", "body": "Former Surrey left-hander Graham Thorpe was renowned as one of the finest English players of his generation, playing exactly 100 Tests and scoring 16 centuries before retiring in 2005.\n\nFormer England cricketer Graham Thorpe has died aged 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board has announced.\n\nThe former Surrey left-hander was renowned as one of the finest English players of his generation, playing exactly 100 Tests and scoring 16 centuries before retiring in 2005.\n\nHe captained England on three occasions and served in various coaching roles for his country between 2010 and 2022.\n\n''There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" a statement from the governing body read.\n\n''More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n''The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nSurrey chair Oli Slipper led the tributes from Thorpe's former county, where he made over 300 appearances in both first-class and List A cricket during a 17-year career.\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nThorpe made his first-class debut for Surrey in the summer of 1988 before establishing himself as a regular in the 1989 season.\n\nHe finally made his England debut at the age of 24, scoring 114 on debut against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993.\n\nThorpe would go on to become a mainstay of the middle-order with his unbeaten double-hundred against New Zealand in Christchurch in 2002 among the highlights of his career - his innings comprised 28 fours and four sixes.\n\nThorpe played sporadically for England until his international retirement in 2005. He went on to begin a coaching career in Australia, where he worked with the likes of Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales, before joining the England and Wales Cricket Board as a batting coach.\n\nHe was appointed Afghanistan head coach in March 2022 following his departure from the England set-up, but did not take up the role due to ill health.", "source": {"uri": "skysports.com", {"uri": "8259781104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:17:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:17:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:16:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.dailypioneer.com/2024/sports/former-england-batter-graham-thorpe-dies-at-55.html", "title": "Former England batter Graham Thorpe dies at 55", "body": "Former England and Surrey batter Graham Thorpe has died aged 55 after battling a \"serious illness\" since 2022, the country's cricket board announced on Monday.\n\nConsidered one of the finest batters of his generation, Thorpe was hospitalised shortly after being named the head coach of Afghanistan in 2022 but the details of his medical condition are not known.\n\nHe is survived by his wife Amanda and four children, Henry, Amelia, Kitty and Emma.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that the ECB shares the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" ECB said in a statement, without giving the exact cause of his death.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world,\" the statement read.\n\nThorpe began his Test career in 1993 with an Ashes century and repeated the feat on the return tour, in Perth in February 1995.\n\nThe left-hander was also instrumental in England's back-to-back series wins in Pakistan and Sri Lanka during the 2000-01 season.\n\nA lynch-pin of England's middle order, he went on to play 100 Tests for England between 1993 and 2005 and averaged 44.66 with 16 centuries.\n\nHe also represented the Three Lions in 82 ODIs, collecting 2830 runs at an average of 37.18.\n\nThorpe enjoyed success at the county level as well. He was picked at the under-11 level by Surrey and played for them for 17 years, scoring close to 20,000 runs for the team.\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed,\" said Oli Slipper, Chair at Surrey CCC.\n\nFollowing his playing career, Thorpe took to coaching.\n\nHe started his coaching career in Australia, where he worked with the likes of Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales. He then joined the England national team set up as a batting coach in 2010.\n\nHe served as an assistant coach for the England men's team under Trevor Bayliss and Chris Silverwood but was axed after the Test side suffered a 0-4 whitewash in the 2021-22 Ashes series Down Under.\n\nHe was then appointed the head coach of Afghanistan in March 2022 but fell ill and couldn't take up the role.\n\n\"Graham Thorpe has recently fallen seriously ill and is currently in hospital receiving treatment,\" The Professional Cricketers' Association said at the time.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage and we ask for privacy for him and his family at this time. {"uri": "2024-08-444291652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:02:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:02:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:27:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://weeklyvoice.com/former-england-cricketer-graham-thorpe-passes-away-at-55/", "title": "Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe passes away at 55", "body": "New Delhi, Aug 5 (VOICE) Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, said the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB). Thorpe played 100 Tests for England between 1993 and 2005, amassing 6,744 runs, including 16 centuries, at an average of 44.66.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport,\" said the ECB in a statement.\n\nThorpe also played 82 ODIs for England, making 2,380 runs at an average of 37.18, including 21 half-centuries, apart from representing Surrey in the domestic circuit from 1988 to 2005. He began his coaching career with the New South Wales side in Australia, where he worked with the likes of David Warner and Steve Smith, before returning to Surrey as their batting coach for two years.\n\nHe then joined the ECB in a national lead batting coach role, working with the England Lions and younger development squads. In 2013, Thorpe became batting coach for the senior England men's white-ball team, who eventually won the 2019 ODI World Cup on home soil.\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed,\" said Surrey Chairman Oli Slipper.\n\nPost that, he served as an assistant coach to Chris Silverwood, and even worked as interim head coach for England's T20I series against Pakistan during Covid-19 pandemic. After England lost the Ashes 4-0, Thrope was sacked from his role and was announced as the new head coach of Afghanistan in March 2022, but fell seriously ill and couldn't take up the role.\n\n\"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans. Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respect the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time,\" concluded Steve Elworthy, Surrey CEO.", "source": {"uri": "weeklyvoice.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Thorpe won 100 Test caps between 1993 and 2005 and scored 16 centuries during a career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation.\n\nFormer England batsman and coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board announced on Monday.\n\nThorpe won 100 Test caps between 1993 and 2005 and scored 16 centuries during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation.\n\nIn total he scored 6,744 Test runs for England at an average of 44.66 and also appeared in 82 one-day internationals.\n\nAlongside his international exploits he enjoyed a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey.\n\nAfter retiring in 2005, he transitioned into coaching, working with the England international teams in various roles between 2010 and 2022.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said in a statement.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\"\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\"\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\nAfter leaving his role with England following defeat to Australia in the 2021-2022 Ashes series, Thorpe became head coach of {"uri": "2024-08-444381688", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:17:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:17:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:08:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3042217-cricket-world-mourns-loss-of-graham-thorpe", "title": "Cricket World Mourns Loss of Graham Thorpe", "body": "Former England cricketer and coach Graham Thorpe has passed away at age 55. Known for his elegant batting, Thorpe played 100 Test matches and 82 ODIs from 1993 to 2005. He later coached England, aiding their 2019 World Cup win. Thorpe was recently appointed as Afghanistan's head coach.\n\nFormer England cricketer and coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced on Monday.\n\nThorpe, renowned for his stylish batting, is considered one of the finest players of his era. Playing from 1993 to 2005, he appeared in 100 Test matches, scoring 6,744 runs with an average of 44.66, including 16 centuries. He also participated in 82 One-Day Internationals (ODIs).\n\nThorpe's hometown club Surrey described him as a 'Surrey and England legend.' 'Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's death,' Surrey posted on social media.\n\nIn a statement on X, the ECB expressed, 'There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death... more than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.'\n\nThorpe served as England's batting coach and assistant coach, playing a key role in their first ODI World Cup victory in 2019. He stepped down in February 2022 after a 4-0 loss in the Ashes. Thorpe was appointed as Afghanistan's head coach in March 2022 but was hospitalised with a serious illness before he could assume the role.\n\n'As batting coach, Thorpe played a key role in England's {"uri": "8259883933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:23:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:23:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:22:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/sports/former-england-batsman-thorpe-dies-aged-55-1850429.html", "title": "Former England Batsman Thorpe Dies Aged 55 - UrduPoint", "body": "London, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 5th Aug, 2024) Former England batsman and coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket board (ECB) announced on Monday.\n\nThorpe won 100 Test caps between 1993 and 2005 and scored 16 centuries during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation.\n\nIn total he scored 6,744 Test runs for England at an average of 44.66 and also appeared in 82 one-day internationals.\n\nAlongside his international exploits he enjoyed a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey.\n\nAfter retiring in 2005, he transitioned into coaching, working with the England international teams in various roles between 2010 and 2022.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said in a statement.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\nHowever, he did not take up the role after the Professional Cricketers' Association revealed in May 2022 Thorpe had fallen seriously ill with an unclear diagnosis.\n\nTributes from stars past and present have poured in for a player that was often a shining light during a difficult time for the England Test side during the 1990s.\n\nThorpe scored 114 on his debut against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993 and would go on to become a mainstay of the middle-order making a highest Test score of 200 not out against New Zealand in 2002.\n\n\"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate,\" former England captain Michael Vaughan posted on X.\n\n\"You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend.\"\n\nCurrent England skipper Ben Stokes posted a photo of him wearing a jersey emblazoned with \"Thorpe 564\", the latter's Test cap number, with a series of heart emojis.\n\nThorpe spent the entirety of his playing career at Surrey and chair Oli Slipper said the country had lost one of its \"great sons\".\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again,\" Slipper said in a Surrey statement.\n\n\"He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe spent 17 years playing for Surrey, earning a regular place in the England test and white-ball teams. He earned 100 test caps for his country, as well as playing in the 1996 and 1999 World Cups. {"uri": "8260093684", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:34:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:34:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:33:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.ndtvprofit.com/sports/former-england-batter-graham-thorpe-dies-at-55", "title": "Former England Batter Graham Thorpe Dies At 55", "body": "Former England and Surrey batter Graham Thorpe has died aged 55 after battling a 'serious illness' since 2022, the country's cricket board announced on Monday.\n\nConsidered one of the finest batters of his generation, Thorpe was hospitalised shortly after being named the head coach of Afghanistan in 2022 but the details of his medical condition are not known.\n\nHe is survived by his wife Amanda and four children, Henry, Amelia, Kitty and Emma.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that the England and Wales Cricket Board shares the news that Graham Thorpe, Member of the Order of the British Empire, has passed away,\" the ECB said in a statement, without giving the exact cause of his death.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world,\" the statement read.\n\nThorpe began his Test career in 1993 with an Ashes century and repeated the feat on the return tour, in Perth in February 1995.\n\nThe left-hander was also instrumental in England's back-to-back series wins in Pakistan and Sri Lanka during the 2000-01 season.\n\nA lynch-pin of England's middle order, he went on to play 100 Tests for England between 1993 and 2005 and averaged 44.66 runs with 16 centuries.\n\nHe also represented the Three Lions in 82 ODIs, collecting 2830 runs at an average of 37.18.\n\nThorpe enjoyed success at the county level as well. He was picked at the under-11 level by Surrey and played for them for 17 years, scoring close to 20,000 runs for the team.\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed,\" said Oli Slipper, Chair at Surrey County Cricket Club.\n\nFollowing his playing career, Thorpe took to coaching.\n\nHe started his coaching career in Australia, where he worked with the likes of Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales. He then joined the England national team set up as a batting coach in 2010.\n\nHe served as an assistant coach for the England men's team under Trevor Bayliss and Chris Silverwood but was axed after the Test side suffered a 0-4 whitewash in the 2021-22 Ashes series Down Under.\n\nHe was then appointed the head coach of Afghanistan in March 2022 but fell ill and couldn't take up the role.\n\n\"Graham Thorpe has recently fallen seriously ill and is currently in hospital receiving treatment,\" The Professional Cricketers' Association said at the time.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8259616541", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:24:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:24:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:23:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/aug/05/graham-thorpe-former-england-cricketer-dies-aged-55", "title": "Graham Thorpe, former England cricketer and coach, dies aged 55", "body": "ECB expresses 'deep shock' in announcementBatter won 100 Test caps and played in 82 ODIs\n\nThe former England cricketer and coach Graham Thorpe, one of the finest Test batters of his generation, has died at the age of 55.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the England and Wales Cricket Board said. \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his team-mates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe was a fluent left-handed batter - and right-handed bowler - who played precisely 100 Tests as well as 82 one-day internationals during a 12-year international career. He played a further 189 first-class matches for Surrey and in all scored 49 first-class centuries, averaging 45.04, before his retirement in 2005.\n\nAs a child Thorpe had been good enough at football to be selected for England Schoolboys and to be offered a trial with Brentford, but chose instead to sign for Surrey, where he was to spend his entire professional career. Initially an all-rounder - on his first-class debut against Leicestershire in 1988 he batted at No 8 and took the wickets of David Gower and Peter Willey - a back injury eventually forced him to stop his seamers and would affect him throughout his time as a player; by the end of his career he would need painkilling injections just to bat.\n\nHe was also affected by issues in his private life. In 2002 he took an indefinite break from cricket as he coped with the drawn-out collapse of his first marriage. The experience of public humiliation in the media and separation from his two children led to what he called a \"total breakdown\", but he returned to the Test team after a 13-month absence in 2003 with a brilliant century against South Africa at the Oval, and the following year was the most successful of his career - in 20 Test innings in 2004, all at No 5, he averaged 73.15.\n\n\"I don't know where my journey is going to take me over the next few years but I'm going to enjoy working it out,\" he said in 2005, after he announced his retirement during the first Test of an Ashes series in which he had hoped to play.\n\n\"Of all the players I played with, [Thorpe] was the one whose state of mind most affected his play,\" Mike Atherton once wrote. \"A happy, contented Graham Thorpe is a world-class player, his presence beneficial to any team. If something off the field is eating away at him, he cannot put it to the back of his mind and concentrate on his cricket.\"\n\nHis relationship with Amanda, who would become his second wife, gave him the stability to do that, and at the end of his playing career he moved into coaching, starting in Australia, where he worked with rising players such as Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales, before joining England, initially as a batting coach in 2010. He had most recently been assistant coach on last winter's difficult Ashes tour, which ended in a 4-0 defeat after which Thorpe, along with the head coach, Chris Silverwood, and the director of cricket, Ashley Giles, lost their jobs as the England and Wales Cricket Board set their sights on a \"red-ball reset\".", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "simon_burnton@theguardian.com", "name": "Simon Burnton", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graham_Thorpe", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.sacricketmag.com/former-england-batsman-thorpe-dies/", "title": "Former England batsman Thorpe dies", "body": "Former England batsman and coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55.\n\nThorpe won 100 Test caps between 1993 and 2005 and scored 16 centuries during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batsmen of his generation.\n\nIn total he scored 6,744 Test runs for England at an average of 44.66 and also appeared in 82 ODIs.\n\nAlongside his international exploits he enjoyed a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey.\n\nAfter retiring in 2005, he transitioned into coaching, working with the England national teams in various roles between 2010 and 2022.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said in a statement.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\nAfter leaving his role with England following defeat to Australia in the 2021-2022 Ashes series, Thorpe became head coach of Afghanistan.\n\nIn May, the Professional Cricketers' Association revealed Thorpe had fallen seriously ill with an unclear {"uri": "8259851053", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:02:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:02:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:01:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.cricketworld.com/former-england-batter-and-coach-graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55/96151.htm", "title": "Former England batter and coach Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Thorpe won 100 Test caps between 1993 and 2005 and scored 16 centuries during a stellar England career and was regarded as one of the best batters of his generation.\n\nIn total he scored 6,744 Test runs for England at an average of 44.66 and also appeared in 82 one-day internationals.\n\nAlongside his international exploits he enjoyed a 17-year spell with his county side Surrey.\n\nAfter retiring in 2005, he transitioned into coaching, working with the England international teams in various roles between 2010 and 2022.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said in a statement.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\nAfter leaving his role with England following defeat to Australia in the 2021-2022 Ashes series, Thorpe was appointed head coach of Afghanistan.\n\nHowever, he did not take up the role after the Professional Cricketers' Association revealed in May 2022 Thorpe had fallen seriously ill with an unclear diagnosis.\n\nTributes from stars past and present have poured in for a player that was often a shining light during a difficult time for the England Test side during the 1990s.\n\nThorpe scored 114 on his debut against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993 and would go on to become a mainstay of the middle-order making a highest Test score of 200 not out against New Zealand in 2002.\n\n\"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate,\" former England captain Michael Vaughan posted on X.\n\n\"You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend.\"\n\nCurrent England skipper Ben Stokes posted a photo of him wearing a jersey emblazoned with \"Thorpe 564\", the latter's Test cap number, with a series of heart emojis.\n\nThorpe spent the entirety of his playing career at Surrey and chair Oli Slipper said the country had lost one of its \"great sons\".\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again,\" Slipper said in a Surrey statement.\n\n\"He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"", "source": {"uri": "cricketworld.com", {"uri": "8259804103", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:32:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:32:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:31:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.newsx.com/world/former-england-cricketer-graham-thorpe-passes-away-at-55-a-tribute-to-a-cricketing-legend/", "title": "Former England Cricketer Graham Thorpe Passes Away at 55: A Tribute to a Cricketing Legend", "body": "Iran May Launch Attack On Israel Today; Netanyahu Considers Preemptive Strike: Report\n\nFormer England cricketer and celebrated coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, leaving the cricketing world in mourning. Renowned for his exceptional skill as a Test batter, Thorpe's passing has evoked deep sadness and tributes from across the cricketing community.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) stated in an official release. \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\"\n\nThe ECB praised Thorpe's contributions to cricket, noting, \"His skill was unquestioned and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his team-mates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\nThorpe, a fluent left-handed batter and right-handed bowler, appeared in precisely 100 Test matches and 82 One-Day Internationals throughout his 12-year international career. He also played 189 first-class matches for Surrey, amassing 49 centuries and maintaining an impressive average of 45.04 before retiring in 2005.\n\nA talented footballer in his youth, Thorpe had the opportunity to represent England Schoolboys and trial with Brentford but chose a career in cricket. He made his first-class debut for Surrey in 1988, where he initially showcased his all-rounder abilities. However, recurring back injuries eventually forced him to cease his seam bowling, and he endured significant physical pain throughout his career, requiring painkilling injections to bat.\n\nThorpe faced personal struggles as well. In 2002, he took an indefinite break from cricket to deal with the collapse of his first marriage, which he described as a \"total breakdown\" amid public scrutiny and separation from his children. Despite these challenges, he made a triumphant return to the Test team in 2003 with a century against South Africa at The Oval. His remarkable form continued into 2004, where he averaged 73.15 in 20 Test innings.\n\nReflecting on his career in 2005, Thorpe said, \"I don't know where my journey is going to take me over the next few years but I'm going to enjoy working it out,\" as he announced his retirement during an Ashes series he had hoped to play in.\n\nMike Atherton, a former teammate, noted, \"Of all the players I played with, [Thorpe] was the one whose state of mind most affected his play. A happy, contented Graham Thorpe is a world-class player, his presence beneficial to any team. If something off the field is eating away at him, he cannot put it to the back of his mind and concentrate on his cricket.\"\n\nThorpe's second marriage to Amanda brought him stability and support. Following his retirement from playing, he transitioned into coaching, initially working with young talent in Australia, including Steve Smith and David Warner, at New South Wales. He later joined the England coaching setup in 2010, serving as a batting coach and, more recently, as an assistant coach during last winter's challenging Ashes tour. His tenure with England ended after the team's 4-0 defeat and the subsequent coaching shake-up.\n\nThe ECB concluded their tribute with heartfelt condolences: \"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. {"uri": "8259778968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:16:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:16:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:15:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://crickettimes.com/2024/08/kumar-sangakkara-to-ben-stokes-cricket-fraternity-mourns-graham-thorpes-tragic-demise/", "title": "Kumar Sangakkara to Ben Stokes: Cricket fraternity mourns Graham Thorpe's tragic demise", "body": "Former England middle-order batter Graham Thorpe has tragically passed away at the age of 55. The England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced the news on Monday (August 5). Thorpe had been battling a serious illness since being appointed as Afghanistan's head coach in March 2022, a role he unfortunately could not take up due to his deteriorating health. The ECB's statement reflected the deep shock and sadness felt across the cricketing world.\n\nThe ECB shared their heartfelt condolences via their official social media channels and website, describing Thorpe as one of England's finest batters. \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike,\" the ECB stated.\n\nThe ECB also highlighted Thorpe's extraordinary skill, achievements, and his impact both as a player and coach. Beyond his playing career, Thorpe made significant contributions as a coach.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game,\"\n\nHe worked with prominent players like Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales and served as England's batting coach and assistant coach. Thorpe also took on the role of interim head coach for England during the COVID-affected summer of 2020 and the fourth Ashes Test in 2021-22. His potential role as Afghanistan's head coach was cut short due to his illness.\n\nThe governing body's statement read further in their official website on X that Thorpe's passing has left a void in the cricketing community. His dedication to the sport, both as a player and a coach, earned him widespread respect and admiration. Thorpe's technical brilliance and his contributions to cricket will be remembered fondly by fans, colleagues, and the cricketing world at large. They offered their deepest condolences go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all his family and friends during this difficult time.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport,\"\n\nThorpe's illustrious international career spanned from 1993 to 2005. He played 100 Tests for England, amassing 6,744 runs at an average of 44.66, including 16 centuries and 39 half-centuries. Thorpe made an impressive debut with a century in the third Test of the 1993 Ashes series against Australia, and he remains England's 15th all-time leading run-scorer in Tests.\n\nIn One Day Internationals (ODIs), Thorpe scored 2,380 runs at an average of 37.18 in 82 matches, showcasing his prowess in the shorter format. His performance in the 1996 World Cup was particularly notable, with an average exceeding 54 across 11 matches. Thorpe also captained England in three ODIs during the 2001 series in Sri Lanka.", "source": {"uri": "crickettimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CricketTimes.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8259789727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:22:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:22:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:21:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/cricket/graham-thorpe-death-health-england-33394910", "title": "Graham Thorpe cause of death and health issues as cricket legend dies aged 55", "body": "Former England cricketer and coach Graham Thorpe, who has died aged 55\n\nGraham Thorpe's death at the age of 55 has hit the cricketing world hard.\n\nA player and coach with England, Thorpe was a popular figure with players past and present. Current skipper Ben Stokes was among those to lead the early tributes, with Michael Vaughan also sending a message after learning of Thorpe's passing.\n\nThe ECB and Surrey County Cricket Club have also shared messages of support. Surrey was where Thorpe spent his entire county career, and he remained a popular figure there after retiring from first-class cricket.\n\nThorpe's health issues came to the fore in 2022, when the Professional Cricketers' Association issued an update. However, the exact nature of Thorpe's condition has been kept a closely guarded secret.\n\n.\"Graham Thorpe has recently fallen seriously ill and is currently in hospital receiving treatment,\" that PCA statement read. \"His prognosis is unclear at this stage and we ask for privacy for him and his family at this time. Our thoughts are with Graham and his family.\"\n\nThorpe had left his coaching role with England earlier in 2022, with Afghanistan appointing him to lead their team. However, he fell ill before taking charge and Jonathan Trott was brought in instead.\n\n\"I'm honoured and excited to have the opportunity to take one of international cricket's most exciting teams through what is a huge year for their development as a team.\" Trott said at the time. \"I also believe that Afghanistan has proved to be a hot-bed of talent, and has produced players capable of playing the game in their own style and with unrivalled passion.\"\n\nShare your fondest memories of Graham Thorpe in the comments section\n\n\"It is with great sadness that the ECB shares the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" an ECB statement read. \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again,\" Surrey CCC chair Oli Slipper said in a statement after learning of Thorpe's passing. \"He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nVaughan, meanwhile, wrote: \"RIP Thorpey .. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career. You were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend ... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family.\"", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tom_victor@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Tom
