{"uri": "8259897671", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:33:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:33:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:30:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/sports/2812325/", "title": "Former England cricket star Graham Thorpe dies aged 55 | UK News - ExBulletin", "body": "Former England player and coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board has announced.\n\nThorpe was regarded as one of the finest batsmen of his generation and played 100 Tests for England.\n\nThe left-handed counter-attacker was a regular in England's Test matches, scoring 16 centuries and playing 82 games for the ODI team, as well as playing for Surrey for 17 years.\n\nHe captained England three times and held various coaching roles for his country between 2010 and 2022.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we have to share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the ECB said.\n\n\"There seem to be no words to express the profound shock we feel at Graham's death. He was more than one of England's greatest ever batters, he was a much-loved member of the cricket family and revered by fans around the world.\n\n\"His skills were unquestionable and his achievements and qualities throughout his 13-year international career brought great joy to his team-mates and the supporters of England and Surrey CCC.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he led the best English men to some incredible victories in all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our thoughts are with his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff and all his family and friends at this unimaginably difficult time. Graham will always be remembered for his extraordinary contribution to the game.\"\n\nDebut century in the Ashes\n\nThorpe, who played for England between 1993 and 2005, scored a century on his debut against Australia at Trent Bridge and quickly became a key player in England's Test and limited overs teams in the mid-1990s and early 2000s.\n\nHis last Test match was against Bangladesh in June 2005. After missing out on the successful Ashes series that summer, he retired from international play.\n\nWith over 6,700 Test runs, he is England's 10th-highest scorer of all time.\n\n'Legend and hero'\n\nMichael Vaughan, who captained Thorpe towards the end of his Test career, wrote on X that he was \"a great player and a brilliant team-mate\" but that he had \"gone far too young\".\n\nEngland's current season opener Ben Duckett also wrote on X: \"Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was lucky enough to work with him.\"\n\nFormer England batsman David Gower said Thorpe was successful against all types of bowling, including runs against West Indies' pace attack and Australian spin great Shane Warne, and \"showed how good he was in all conditions. He scored runs at home, he scored runs away.\"\n\nGower noted that Thorpe occasionally doubted himself, such as when he left the 2001-2 tour of India early, but said most people looking back on his career will remember his \"Ashes centuries, three of them, centuries against the West Indies, centuries pretty much everywhere\".\n\nFormer England player Shaun Udal, who played with Thorpe, described him at X as a \"little legend\".\n\nA 'warrior' in the line-up\n\nSurrey chief executive Steve Elworthy said on X: \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He delivered remarkable services for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\"\n\nDean Headley, who played with Thorpe in the 1997 Ashes, called him on X \"a warrior in our batting line-up and a player who is not talked about enough because of his elegance and style of play.\"\n\nThorpe remained active after his retirement as a player and moved to New South Wales, where he worked with the young Steve Smith and David Warner, Australia's future batting stars.\n\nHe returned to England to work as a batting coach.\n\nIn 2022, he led the team to a thrilling draw in the Sydney Test after head coach Chris Silverwood contracted COVID-19, but stepped down from his role following the Ashes series defeat.\n\nThorpe was appointed Afghanistan coach in July but fell {"uri": "2024-08-444258589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:31:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:31:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:12:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/sport/5312335/who-is-graham-thorpe-wife-amanda/", "title": "A look at the life of the late Graham Thorpe's wife Amanda", "body": "FORMER England cricketer Graham Thorpe has died aged 55.\n\nThe late cricketer leaves behind his family and wife Amanda. Here we take a look at their relationship.\n\nWho is Graham Thorpe's wife Amanda?\n\nGraham Thorpe was married to wife Amanda who he wed in 2007.\n\nThe pair welcomed a daughter in 2005.\n\nThorpe's life with Amanda was always kept extremely private.\n\nIt is not known how the couple met or what she does for a living.\n\nBefore he married Amanda, Thorpe was wed to his first wife Nicole.\n\nThe former couple married in 1995, but divorced in 2002.\n\nDuring their relationship the pair welcomed a son and daughter, born in 1996 and 1999 respectively.\n\nAmanda also has an older daughter from a previous relationship.\n\nThe England and Wales Cricket Board said: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\nIn a statement, the ECB added: \"The cricket world is in mourning today.\n\n\"Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\n\n\"We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe's death came two years after his family said he had become seriously ill with an \"unclear\" prognosis.\n\nDuring his life, the talented cricketeer played for England in 100 Test Matches and 82 One Day International games.\n\nThe batsman also enjoyed a 17-year career at The Oval with Surrey CCC.\n\nHe was named Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1997 after netting back-to-back centuries and ranking top scorer in the Ashes.\n\nHe deputised as England's captain for three ODI games over his long career.\n\nIn 2011 fellow England legend David Gower ranked Thorpe as one of the two best English batsmen he had ever encountered.\n\nWhat tributes have been made for Graham Thorpe?\n\nOli Slipper, Chair at Surrey CCC said: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey.\n\n\"There is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again.\n\n\"He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, CEO at Surrey CCC, said \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing.\n\n\"He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to.\n\n\"We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly {"uri": "8259700183", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:23:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:23:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:22:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/firstcricket/sports-news/graham-thorpe-england-batter-passes-away-aged-55-13801014.html", "title": "Graham Thorpe, former England batter, passes away aged 55", "body": "Graham Thorpe also served as England's batting coach and assistant coach. Reuters\n\nFormer England batter Graham Thorpe has passed away aged 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board announced on Monday. The former batter played 100 Tests for England between 1993 and 2005 and 82 ODIs.\n\nThe southpaw scored 6,744 runs in Tests including 16 hundreds at an average of 44.66.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said on in a statement. \"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his team-mates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\n\n\"We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe also served as England's batting coach and assistant coach till February 2022 when he stepped down after a 4-0 loss in the Ashes. {"uri": "8259763079", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:06:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:06:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:04:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/29685338/graham-thorpe-seriously-ill-death/", "title": "Graham Thorpe's health battle left him 'seriously ill' years before tragic death", "body": "GRAHAM Thorpe had fallen \"seriously ill\" in hospital just two years before his tragic death at age 55.\n\nThorpe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nIn May 2022, the Professional Cricketers' Association shared a statement on behalf of Thorpe's family, revealing that the England legend had \"fallen seriously ill\" and was in hospital receiving treatment.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage... our thoughts are with Graham and his family,\" the statement read.\n\nNow, two years later, the England and Wales Cricket Board have revealed the cricketer's death at age 55.\n\nA statement read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022.\n\nThorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nThe Professional Cricketers' Association shared a statement on behalf of Thorpe's family in May 2022, saying the England legend had \"fallen seriously ill\" and was in hospital receiving treatment.\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage... our thoughts are with Graham and his family,\" the {"uri": "2024-08-444455608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:22:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:22:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/cricket/cricket-world-rocked-by-graham-thorpes-shock-death-at-55/news-story/ed8a0bc6709f344da0430289730f4f5c", "title": "Cricket world rocked by England legend Graham Thorpe's shock death at 55", "body": "The cricket world has been left in shock and mourning after the death of former England batter Graham Thorpe at the age of 55.\n\nThe left-hander has been remembered as one of the greatest English players of his generation, having played 100 Tests and scored 6744 runs at an average off 44.66, including 16 centuries.\n\nHe also captained England on three occasions.\n\nThorpe also represented England 82 times in One Day Internationals with 2380 runs at 37.18 and a highest score of 89.\n\nWatch every ball of the England v Sri Lanka test series LIVE & exclusive to Fox Cricket, available on Kayo. New to Kayo? Start your free trial today >\n\nHe also played 341 first-class matches, scoring 21,937 runs, including 49 centuries as well as 354 domestic one-day matches that netted 10,871 runs. By any mark it was an incredible career.\n\nAfter his playing days, Thorpe held several coaching roles for England between 2010 and 2022.\n\nIn March 2022, Thorpe was announced as the new head coach of Afghanistan but was unable to take up the role after falling seriously ill and being hospitalised for treatment.\n\nThe cricket world was quick to pay tribute.\n\nThe England and Wales Cricket Board released a statement announcing the news.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the statement read.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nSurrey, the club where he played his entire county career, also remembered Thorpe as a \"legend\".\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions,\" Surrey Cricket Club chair Oli Slipper said.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nEngland supporters club The Barmy Army posted simply: \"Tragic news. Rest in peace.\"\n\nPlayers past and present have also offered their condolences.\n\nFormer England captain Michael Vaughan tweeted: \"RIP Thorpey .. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant teammate.\n\n\"You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend ... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.\"\n\nCurrent England opening batter Ben Duckett wrote: \"Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him. My thoughts go out to all of his friends and family during this tough time.\"\n\nSri Lankan legend Kumar Sangakkara posted: \"Rest in Peace Thorpey. Great man and legend. Thoughts with his family, loved ones and friends. Gone far too early.\"\n\nFormer Aussie star and coach Darren Lehmann simply tweeted three tear emojis.\n\nSouth African great Herschelle Gibbs wrote: \"Such sad news this, wonderful batsman but a great gent most importantly. Condolences to his family and friends.\"\n\nEx-England star turned cricket correspondent Derek Pringle wrote: \"Graham Thorpe had his demons but this is just such a sad day.....RIP Thorpey, a fabulous cricketer and team mate.\"\n\nJournalist Alison Mitchell commented: \"This is desperately tragic news. Aged just 55.\"\n\nThorpe made his England debut at the age of 24 in 1993 in an Ashes Test against Australia, where he scored 114 at Trent Bridge.\n\nHe would become a staple of the England middle-order until his international retirement in 2005.\n\nHe started his coaching career in Australia, where he coached at NSW between 2005 and 2008, before returning to England where he held several roles until he was dismissed after England's 4-0 loss in the 2021-22 Ashes series in Australia.\n\nOriginally published as Cricket world rocked by Graham Thorpe's shock death at 55", "source": {"uri": "8260006386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:41:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:41:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:38:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.etvbharat.com/en/!sports/graham-thorpe-passed-away-at-the-age-of-55-enn24080504853", "title": "Cricket World Saddened; Cricketer Who Once Played With Sachin Tendulkar and Virender Sehwag Passes Away", "body": "Thorpe made his first-class debut for Surrey in 1898 and made it into the international side in 1993 at the age of 24. He became a key player for the English side in the middle order soon and was one of the mainstays in the team.\n\nFormer England cricket Graham Thrope has passed away at the age of 55. The England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) confirmed the development on August 5, Monday. Thorpe represented England from 1993 to 205 in 100 Tests while he was also a part of the English side in 82 ODIs. The English cricketer scored 6,744 Test runs smashing 16 hundreds with an average of 44.66.\n\nECB shared the news through an official release.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that the ECB shares the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" ECB stated in an official release.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. He played 100 test matches between 1993 and 2005, scoring 6,744 runs with an average of 44.66 including 16 centuries.\n\nThe left-handed middle-order batter also played 82 One-Day Internationals (ODIs).\n\nThorpe's hometown club Surrey, whom he represented in first-class cricket, called him a \"Surrey and England legend.\"\n\n\"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham\u00b4s death,\" Surrey posted on social media.\n\nIn a post on X the ECB said: \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death ... more than one of England\u00b4s finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. He stepped down in February 2022 after a 4-0 loss in the Ashes.\n\nHe was appointed as Afghanistan's head coach in March 2022, but was hospitalised with a serious illness before he could join the team.\n\n\"As batting coach, Thorpe played a key role in England\u00b4s resurgence in white-ball cricket,\" the Marylebone Cricket Club (MCC), where Thorpe was an honorary life member, said in a social media post. {"uri": "8259654594", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:55:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:55:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:51:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/cricket/graham-thorpe-former-england-cricketer-and-coach-dies-aged-55-101722842972429.html", "title": "Graham Thorpe, former England cricketer and coach, dies aged 55", "body": "Former England cricketer and coach Graham Thorpe passed away on Monday, the England and Wales Cricket Board announced. He was 55. Thorpe played 100 Tests and 82 ODIs for England between 1993 and 2005, and scored 6,744 runs in the longer format, which included 16 centuries, at an average of 44.66. The stylish left-handed batter also smashed 2380 runs laced with 21 fifties at an average of 37.18.\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time,\" a statement from the ECB read.\n\nThorpe also spent 17 years playing for Surrey, where he made 241 appearances in first-class cricket and 271 List A games, scoring over 20,000 runs for the county side. His former county also mourned his sad loss as chairman Oli Slipper hailed his legacy.\n\nSlipper said: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey's CEO, added: \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death. More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world,\" the ECB statement read as quoted by ICC.\n\nIt then mentioned Thorpe's contribution to England cricket over the years.\n\nAlso Read | Chelsea's Conor Gallagher Agrees to 33 Million Euro Move to Atletico Madrid: Report.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game,\" the ECB statement added.\n\nThorpe made his international debut in 1993 and was the mainstay of the English batting throughout the late 90s and early 2000s. The southpaw played 100 Tests and scored 6744 runs at an average of 44.66, with 16 hundreds and 39 fifties to his name. His highest score was 200*.\n\nIn ODIs, the gritty batter scored 2380 runs at an average of 37.18 with 21 fifties. He appeared at two ICC Men's Cricket World Cups, scoring 254 runs at the 1996 edition in Sri Lanka and then contributing 125 runs three years later at the event in England, Netherlands, Scotland, Ireland and Wales.\n\nIn the ICC batting rankings, Thorpe peaked at No.3 in Tests ahead of England's tour of the West Indies in 1998. His peak in the ODI rankings was No.10, the release added.\n\nAfter retiring from cricket in 2005, Thorpe held coaching positions with New South Wales, Surrey and England Men's side.\n\nThe legendary player was involved with the England setup as a coach for the majority of the 2010s and was part of the coaching hierarchy in the role of batting coach that netted the European side of the 2019 World Cup on home soil in thrilling fashion.\n\nThorpe was recently England's assistant coach up until the 2021/22 Ashes tour of Australia. He was subsequently appointed as Afghanistan's head coach in March 2022, but couldn't take up the position due to his illness. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\"\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, CEO at Surrey CCC, also paid tribute: \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. {"uri": "8259948202", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:03:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:03:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:02:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/sport/national/24497062.former-england-surrey-batter-graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55/", "title": "Former England and Surrey batter Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Thorpe made his international debut in 1993 and scored a century on his first Ashes appearance, becoming the first England player to do so in 20 years.\n\nThorpe was an England regular and went on to play 100 Tests, scoring 16 centuries and featuring 82 times for the ODI side, as well as enjoying a 17-year career with Surrey.\n\nHis final Test appearance came in June 2005 before he was omitted from that summer's victorious Ashes series and called time on his international career.\n\nA statement from the England and Wales Cricket Board read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe stayed in the game after his retirement from playing, moving to New South Wales where he worked with a young Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nHe returned to work with England between 2010 and 2022. Thorpe took charge of his country in the familiar surroundings of the Sydney Cricket Ground after Chris Silverwood was laid low by coronavirus, securing a nailbiting draw to avoid a seemingly inevitable Ashes whitewash.\n\nEngland Test captain Ben Stokes paid tribute to Thorpe with a love heart emoji alongside a picture on his social-media channels, while Joe Root labelled him as a \"hero\" in an emotional post on his Instagram story.\n\n\"Hero, mentor and so much more! Rest in peace and thanks for everything,\" Root said.\n\nStuart Broad added on his Instagram story: \"Genuinely gutted. Loved Thorpey.\n\n\"As a kid I would run in from the garden to watch him bat. The Kookaburra Bubble and that famous knee up pull shot.\n\n\"Got to know him through his coaching roles with England and he was a wonderful person with a beautiful family. Thinking of everyone who knew him today and everyone who was inspired by him.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey chief executive, said \"Everyone associated with the club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nMichael Vaughan, who captained Thorpe towards the end of his Test career, wrote on X: \"RIP Thorpey. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career, you were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family xxx.\"\n\nCurrent England opener Ben Duckett also wrote on X, saying: \"Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. {"uri": "8259795044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:28:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:28:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:25:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/sports/2812291/", "title": "Graham Thorpe: Former England and Surrey player dies aged 55 | Cricket News - ExBulletin", "body": "Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board has announced.\n\nThe former Surrey left-handed hurler was regarded as one of the finest English players of his generation, playing exactly 100 Tests and scoring 16 centuries before retiring in 2005.\n\nHe captained England three times and held various coaching roles for his country between 2010 and 2022.\n\n\"There seem to be no adequate words to express the profound shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the governing body said in a statement.\n\n''More than one of England's greatest ever batsmen, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans the world over.\n\n\"His skills were unquestionable and his abilities and achievements in an international career spanning 13 years brought so much happiness to his team-mates and the supporters of England and Surrey CCC. Later, as a coach, he led the best talent of the England men to some incredible victories in all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our thoughts are with his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff and all his family and friends at this unimaginably difficult time. Graham will always be remembered for his extraordinary contribution to the game.\"\n\nSurrey chairman Oli Slipper led the tributes from Thorpe's former county, where he played more than 300 games in both first-class and List A cricket during a 17-year career.\n\n\"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is overwhelming sadness that he will no longer walk through the gates of the Oval. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the club by wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He has made an extraordinary contribution to the club as a cricketer and as a person and we will miss him immensely.\"\n\nFormer and current players also paid tribute to Thorpe, including one of his former England captains, Michael Vaughan.\n\n\"RIP Thorpey. Thank you for all the advice during my career, you were a great player and a brilliant teammate,\" Vaughan posted on X.\n\n\"You went far too young but you leave a legend of English cricket... My thoughts are with everyone who knew Thorpey and all the family xxx.\"\n\nCurrent England season opener Ben Duckett also wrote on X: \"Heartbreaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was lucky enough to work with him.\n\n\"My thoughts are with all his friends and family during this difficult time.\"\n\nThorpe made his First Division debut for Surrey in the summer of 1988, developing into a regular in the 1989 season.\n\nHe eventually made his debut for England at the age of 24, scoring 114 runs on his debut against Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993.\n\nThorpe would become a regular in the middle order. His unbeaten double hundred against New Zealand at Christchurch in 2002 was one of the highlights of his career. He hit 28 fours and four sixes in his innings.\n\nThorpe played sporadically for England until his international retirement in 2005. He began a coaching career in Australia, working with players such as Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales, before joining the England and Wales Cricket Board as batting coach.\n\nIn March {"uri": "8260023892", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:50:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:50:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:50:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cricket/graham-thorpes-death-came-after-29679512", "title": "Graham Thorpe's death came after serious illness was revealed in statement", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nThe cricketing world has been dealt a heavy blow as it mourns the loss of former England batsman Graham Thorpe, who has died aged 55.\n\nThorpe, with 100 test caps under his belt and a remarkable double century against New Zealand among his many achievements, spent over 10 glorious years at Surrey County Cricket Club, leaving an indelible mark on the grounds he graced. Renowned not just for his prowess on the pitch, but also his work as a coach and broadcaster post-retirement.\n\nHis passing comes barely two years after a severe health scare that saw him admitted to hospital. In 2022, grappling with ill health, the Professional Cricketers' Association conveyed a message from Thorpe's family that read: \"Graham Thorpe has recently fallen seriously ill and is currently in hospital receiving treatment\n\n\"His prognosis is unclear at this stage and we ask for privacy for him and his family at this time. Our thoughts are with Graham and his family.\"\n\nSince news of his death broke, there has been a deluge of tributes honouring the man affectionately known throughout cricketing circles. Due to begin coaching Afghanistan's national team last year, he was unable to take up the position due to his ill health.\n\nSurrey CCC, where Thorpe's brilliance both as a player and person shone, are among those expressing deep sorrow. Oli Slipper, Chair of Surrey CCC, spoke poignantly of Thorpe's legacy, stating: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\"\n\nWith profound sadness, the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced the death of Graham Thorpe, MBE, through a statement. \"It is with great sadness that the ECB shares the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away,\" the statement revealed as it reacted to the news of his untimely passing.\n\nIt continued: \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"Graham Thorpe was much more than one of England's most exceptional talents with the bat. To his colleagues and fans around the globe, he was an esteemed and cherished figure.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\nThe loss leaves the cricketing world in heartfelt sorrow. The statement expressed deep condolences: \"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nReflecting on his legacy, England captain Ben Stokes and ex-captain Michael Vaughan shared their memories and respects. Vaughan paid his tribute, saying, \"RIP Thorpey .. Thanks for all the advice throughout my career,\" acknowledging the positive impact Graham had on his and many others' careers.\n\nHe lauded the late cricketer's attributes both on and off the pitch: \"You were a great player and a brilliant team-mate. You have gone far too young but you leave as an England cricket legend ... Thoughts with all who knew Thorpey and to all the family.\"", "source": {"uri": "walesonline.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "WalesOnline"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tom_victor@walesonline.co.uk", {"uri": "8259633475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:37:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:37:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:36:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/graham-thorpe-dies-tributes-paid-29677249", "title": "Graham Thorpe dies as tributes paid to England cricket legend - Liverpool Echo", "body": "The former England batter and coach has died at the age of 55\n\nFormer England batter Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55. The England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) released a heartfelt statement this morning announcing his death.\n\nThorpe's illustrious career spanned 17 years with Surrey, securing him a steadfast position in both the England test and white-ball squads. He proudly donned the England cap 100 times in tests, and participated in the 1996 and 1999 World Cups, reports the Mirror.\n\nThe ECB statement read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\"\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\"\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nSurrey CCC, his long-time county team, are also deeply feeling the loss, with chairman Oli Slipper praising Thorpe's enduring legacy.\n\nMr Slipper said: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSurrey's CEO Steve Elworthy also paid tribute, saying: \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans. Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. {"uri": "8259615020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:23:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:23:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:22:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cricket/graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55-29677174", "title": "Graham Thorpe dies aged 55 as tribute paid to England cricketer", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nEngland cricketer Graham Thorpe has died aged 55.\n\nThe Surrey batsman made his international debut in 1993 and went on to be one of the most respected players in the game.\n\nHe appeared in 100 Test matches for his country before moving into coaching, as well doing some punditry work.\n\nHe was made an MBE in 2006.\n\nIn a statement, the England and Wales Cricket Board said on Monday morning: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nSurrey chairman Oli Slipper added: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey's CEO, said: \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans. Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. Thorpe had been seriously ill and hospitalized in 2022, with an unclear prognosis at the time.\n\nThe left-handed batter played 182 times for England across Tests and ODIs during his 13-year international career, featuring in 100 Tests and 82 ODIs. Thorpe began his career impressively, scoring an Ashes century on his debut in 1993 at Trent Bridge.\n\nThroughout his career, Thorpe scored 16 centuries and accumulated 6,744 runs in Tests, alongside 2,380 runs in ODIs. He was also a standout performer at the county level, amassing 21,937 runs for Surrey in First Class cricket, with 49 centuries and an average of 45.04.\n\nOli Slipper, the Chair of Surrey Cricket Club offered his tributes to the swashbuckling batter: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nIn their statement, ECB said: \"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. He wed his second wife Amanda in 2007, after marrying Nicole back in 1995. They divorced seven years later, and the pail welcomed their son and daughter years before their split.\n\nAmanda was always keen to keep out of the spotlight and it is not known what she does for a living, but was by his side when he collected his MBE with their daughters Kitty and Emma also posing for a photo after he was honoured for his services to British sports at Buckingham Palace.\n\nToday the England and Wales Cricket Board announced the heartbreaking news, after the cricket battled serious illness since 2022. In a statement, the ECB said: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nGraham spent 17 years playing for Surrey, earning a regular place in the England Test and ODI teams. He earned 100 Test caps for his country, as well as playing in the 1996 and 1999 World Cups.\n\nA lynchpin of England's middle order, Thorpe struck Over 6,700 Test runs at an average of almost 45, including 16 centuries. His former county are also now mourning his sad loss, with Surrey chairman Oli Slipper hailing his legacy.\n\nSlipper said: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, Surrey's CEO, added: \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans. Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. {"uri": "8259737899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:49:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:49:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:48:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/29683063/graham-thorpe-dead-england-best-batsmen-stokes/", "title": "Thorpe was open, with self-depreciating humour and one of England's best batsmen", "body": "GRAHAM THORPE, who has died aged 55, was England's best batsmen between the end of David Gower's career and the start of Kevin Pietersen's.\n\nIndeed, many reckon he was at least as good as either Gower or Pietersen.\n\nThorpe was a nuggety left-hander who could attack or defend, display a carefree approach or iron-willed patience.\n\nHe was good against fast bowling and an absolute master facing spin.\n\nHis innings of 113 not out against Sri Lanka in Colombo in 2001 was one of the finest ever played for England.\n\nIt is rarely mentioned alongside the barnstorming efforts of Stokes or Ian Botham but, make no mistake, it was an all-time heroic performance in extreme heat against top-class spin.\n\nThorpe scored 32 not out in the second innings (out of 74-6) as England won by four wickets.\n\nHe was so shattered that he missed the team party that evening.\n\nThorpe was born in Farnham, Surrey, and the story goes that he switched to left-handed because the legside boundary in his back garden was shorter that side.\n\nHe was good enough at football to play for England age-group teams but opted for cricket.\n\nHe played for Surrey, England A and, in 1993, scored an Ashes century on his Test debut against Australia at Trent Bridge.\n\nHe made another brilliant century - 138 - against the Aussies at Edgbaston in 1997. He and Nasser Hussain put on 288 for the fourth wicket and England won by nine wickets.\n\nIt was an almost unique match of England domination in an era of ritual hammerings by the old enemy.\n\nThorpe's highest Test score was a blazing 200 not out from just 231 balls against New Zealand in Christchurch in 2002.\n\nIt was eclipsed by Nathan Astle's brutal 222 from 168 deliveries in the same match but England still won comfortably.\n\nIn another famous win, Thorpe scored 64 not out as England beat Pakistan in Karachi in 2000 by six wickets.\n\nIt was virtually dark at the end and there were no floodlights.\n\nThorpe's final Test innings was 66 not out against Bangladesh in 2005 but England decided to drop him to accommodate the recently-qualified Pietersen.\n\nSo Thorpe took no part in the greatest Test series of all time against Australia that summer.\n\nHe scored 16 centuries in exactly 100 Tests with an average of 44.66.\n\nThorpe moved into coaching, working in Australia for New South Wales, where his charges included youngsters called David Warner and Steve Smith.\n\nHe was England's lead batting coach for several years and an assistant-coach on the Ashes tour of 2021-22.\n\nAway from the pitch, Thorpe's first marriage broke down very publicly and he missed some cricket as a result. He had two children.\n\nThorpe could be maudlin and would sometimes spend hours telling people about his problems.\n\nHe found love again and married Amanda and she became a regular when he toured as part of England's coaching team.\n\nHe was his own man - he was fined \u00a31,000 for refusing to attend an official function during the 1999 World Cup, for example - but I liked him a lot.\n\nHe was open, honest and with a self-deprecating humour.\n\nAfter England's defeat in the Fifth Test in Hobart, Thorpe lit a cigar while drinking indoors with players from both teams.\n\nThe police were called and he filmed their arrival on his 'phone, providing a commentary. Within hours, the footage went public.\n\nThorpe lost his job after England's 0-4 defeat in that series but, within weeks, he was hired to become head coach of Afghanistan.\n\nHe never took up that position, however, and in May of 2022, the PCA put out a statement revealing that Thorpe was \"seriously ill\" in hospital.\n\nHe was not seen again in cricket circles after that although some of his former team-mates tried to keep in touch.\n\nThe cricket world will be deeply shocked and saddened by his passing.\n\nThe ECB said in a statement: \"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his team-mates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\n\n\"We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "john_etheridge@thesun.co.uk", "name": "John Etheridge", "type": {"uri": "2024-08-444255133", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:28:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:28:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:18:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.sussexexpress.co.uk/sport/cricket/surrey-county-cricket/former-surrey-and-england-batter-graham-thorpe-dies-aged-55-4728934", "title": "'He was a beloved member of the cricket family' - Former Surrey and England batter Graham Thorpe dies aged 55", "body": "Former Surrey and England cricketerGraham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) have confirmed.\n\nA short statement from the ECB read: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time. We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nOli Slipper, Chair at Surrey CCC said \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions.\n\n\"He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nSteve Elworthy, CEO at Surrey CCC, said \"Everyone associated with the Club is devastated by the tragic news of Graham's passing. He achieved remarkable feats for club and country and was a hero to so many cricket fans.\n\n\"Our thoughts and condolences are with Graham's family and friends, to whom we will offer any support that we are able to. We ask that everyone respects the privacy of the family at this incredibly difficult time.\"\n\nCurrent England Test opener Ben Duckett posted on X: \"Heart-breaking to see Thorpey has passed away. He was one of my heroes growing up and I was fortunate to work with him. {"uri": "2024-08-444296416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:05:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:05:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:02:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3042124-cricket-mourns-the-loss-of-graham-thorpe-legendary-england-batsman", "title": "Cricket Mourns the Loss of Graham Thorpe, Legendary England Batsman", "body": "Graham Thorpe, former England and Surrey cricketer, has passed away at the age of 55 after battling a serious illness since 2022. Thorpe, revered for his batting prowess, played 100 Tests and 82 ODIs for England. He also had a successful coaching career, impacting players like Steve Smith and David Warner.\n\nGraham Thorpe, the esteemed former England and Surrey cricketer, has died at the age of 55 after battling a serious illness since 2022, the country's cricket board confirmed on Monday.\n\nKnown as one of the finest batters of his era, Thorpe was hospitalized shortly after being named the head coach of Afghanistan in 2022, though details of his medical condition were never disclosed.\n\nThorpe leaves behind his wife Amanda and four children: Henry, Amelia, Kitty, and Emma.\n\nIn a statement, the ECB expressed profound sorrow over Thorpe's death, calling him not only one of England's most extraordinary batters but also a cherished member of the cricketing family worldwide.\n\nUpon starting his Test career in 1993, Thorpe made an indelible mark with a century during an Ashes series. The left-handed batter was pivotal in England's series wins in Pakistan and Sri Lanka during the 2000-01 season.\n\nOver his illustrious career, he played 100 Tests between 1993 and 2005, averaging 44.66 with 16 centuries. Additionally, he played 82 ODIs, amassing 2830 runs at an average of 37.18.\n\nThorpe's contributions were equally noteworthy at the county level, where he played for Surrey for 17 years and scored nearly 20,000 runs.\n\nSurrey CCC Chair, Oli Slipper, highlighted Thorpe's immense contributions to the club both on and off the field, expressing deep sorrow at his passing.\n\nAfter his playing career, Thorpe transitioned seamlessly into coaching, initially in Australia and later with the England national team as a batting coach. Despite being axed following England's 0-4 Ashes defeat in 2021-22, he was appointed the head coach of Afghanistan in March 2022 but fell ill before assuming the role.\n\nThe Professional Cricketers' Association had earlier stated Thorpe was seriously ill and receiving hospital treatment, requesting privacy for his family.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": His family revealed he had been diagnosed with a serious illness back in March of 2022.\"\n\nJohn went on to remember Thorpe's storied career: \"He was due to take up a coaching role at the time, he had a really successful career at the time especially as a batsman with England and Surrey where he spent his entire career.\", reports the Express.\n\nDetailing Thorpe's cricket journey, Watson added, \"He played 100 tests for his country between 1993 and 2005 before moving into coaching. He was the England mens batting coach but that news this morning involving Graham Thorpe the former England cricketer Graham Thorpe who has died at the age of 55,\" he continued.\n\nBen acknowledged his colleague's report, saying: \"John for now, thanks and I know you're back shortly with us.\" Earlier today, the England and Wales Cricket Board also issued a heartfelt statement honouring Graham's memory and confirming the news of his passing.\n\nIn a heartfelt tribute, the cricket board announced: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death.\"\n\nThey continued to express their sorrow: \"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\"\n\nThe statement further honoured his coaching legacy: \"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\"\n\nConcluding their message, they added: \"We will always {"uri": "2024-08-444211941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:46:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:46:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.cricbuzz.com/cricket-news/131253/graham-thorpe-passes-away", "title": "Graham Thorpe passes away", "body": "Former England and Surrey cricketer Graham Thorpe passed away at the age of 55 on August 5. Thorpe had been admitted to hospital in 2022 having fallen seriously ill at the time with the prognosis unclear at that stage. Surrey Cricket and the England & Wales Cricket Board (ECB) confirmed the tragic news in an official statement.\n\nThe left-handed batter played 182 times for England across Tests and ODIs in a 13-year international career (100 Tests, 82 ODIs). He started his career in fine fashion with an Ashes century on debut in 1993 at Trent Bridge.\n\nHe scored 16 centuries and amassed 6,744 runs in Tests while making 2,380 runs in ODIs. A great at the county level too, Thorpe scored 21,937 runs for Surrey in First Class cricket, with 49 centuries to his name and an average of 45.04.\n\nOli Slipper, the Chair of Surrey Cricket Club offered his tributes to the swashbuckling batter: \"Graham is one of the great sons of Surrey and there is an overwhelming sadness that he will not walk through the gates of the Oval again. He is a legend of Surrey and brought great pride to the Club wearing both the Three Feathers and the Three Lions. He made outstanding contributions to the Club as a cricketer, and as a man, and he will be so sorely missed.\"\n\nIn their statement, ECB said: \"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike. Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\"\n\nMore to follow...", "source": {"uri": "cricbuzz.com", "dataType": "news", His family revealed he had been diagnosed with a serious illness back in March of 2022.\"\n\nDetailing Thorpe's achievements, sports presenter John Watson said: \"He was due to take up a coaching role at the time, he had a really successful career at the time especially as a batsman with England and Surrey where he spent his entire career.\"\n\n\"He played 100 tests for his country between 1993 and 2005 before moving into coaching. He was the England mens batting coach but that news this morning involving Graham Thorpe the former England cricketer Graham Thorpe who has died at the age of 55,\" Watson elaborated on Thorpe's illustrious career and untimely death, reports the Express.\n\nBen then acknowledged his colleague's report, saying, \"John for now, thanks and I know you're back shortly with us.\"\n\nEarlier in the day, the England and Wales Cricket Board had issued a statement honouring Graham and confirming the news of his passing.\n\nThe cricket world is reeling from the tragic news that England legend and Surrey icon, Graham Thorpe, MBE, has sadly passed away. The statement issued was clear about the impact of the loss: \"It is with great sadness that we share the news that Graham Thorpe, MBE, has passed away. His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his teammates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\"\n\nThey also highlighted his successful coaching career: \"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England Men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game. The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\"\n\nAnd they concluded by ensuring his legacy would endure, stating: \"We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nBBC Breakfast airs daily on BBC One at 6am\n\nWant all the biggest Showbiz and TV news straight to your inbox? {"uri": "2024-08-444258807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:31:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:31:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:26:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://pragativadi.com/former-england-cricketer-graham-thorpe-passes-away-aged-55/", "title": "Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe passes away aged 55 | Pragativadi | Odisha News, Breaking News Odisha, Latest Odisha News", "body": "London: Former England cricketer Graham Thorpe has passed away at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board confirmed on Monday, August 5.\n\nThorpe represented England in 100 Test matches from 1993 to 2005 and participated in 82 One Day Internationals (ODIs) during this period. He amassed 6,744 runs in Test cricket for England, including 16 centuries, averaging 44.66.\n\nThe ECB stated on their website on Monday, announcing Thorpe's passing.\n\n\"With profound sorrow, the ECB announces the death of Graham Thorpe, MBE.\"\n\n\"Words seem inadequate to express the deep shock we feel at the loss of Graham.\"\n\n\"He was more than one of England's greatest-ever batsmen; he was a cherished member of the cricket community, esteemed by fans worldwide. His talent was undeniable, and his accomplishments over a 13-year international career brought immense joy to his colleagues and the supporters of England and Surrey CCC. Subsequently, as a coach, he led England's Men's team to remarkable triumphs in all formats of the game.\"\n\n\"Today, the cricket world grieves. Our thoughts are with his wife Amanda, his children, his father Geoff, and all his family and friends during this incredibly tough time. Graham's extraordinary contributions to cricket will forever be remembered,\" the ECB statement read.\n\nGraham Thorpe debuted in first-class cricket for Surrey in the summer of 1988 and became a consistent player in the 1989 season. He made his England debut in 1993 at the age of 24, scoring an impressive 114 runs against Australia at Trent Bridge.\n\nA pivotal figure in England's batting lineup, Thorpe's unbeaten double-century against New Zealand in Christchurch in 2002 remains a standout performance. The innings featured 28 fours and four sixes.\n\nDespite sporadic appearances, he retired from international cricket in 2005 and subsequently moved into coaching.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-444299965", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:08:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:08:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:49:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/graham-thorpe-finest-england-middle-084935027.html", "title": "Graham Thorpe, finest England middle-order batsman of his era, who averaged 44.66 over 100 Tests - obituary", "body": "Graham Thorpe, finest England middle-order batsman of his era, who averaged 44.66 over 100 Tests - obituary\n\nTelegraph Obituaries\n\n5 August 2024 at 10:49 am\n\nGraham Thorpe, who has died aged 55, was the finest England middle-order batsman of his era, a nuggety left-hander who made a century on his debut against a strong Australian attack and who was as adept against spin as he was pace. He played in 100 Test matches and, but for back trouble and the emergence of Kevin Pietersen, would have remained an international cricketer for longer.\n\nAlthough a technically sound batsman brought up on true pitches at the Oval, Thorpe did not fit into the mould of classic England stroke-makers. He might well have been drawn to football, for he was talented enough to represent England under-18s. His character was more complicated than his batting and he could be truculent, and sometimes suffered from depression, yet he was also single-minded and fearless.\n\nWhen Wisden named Thorpe as one of its five cricketers of the year in 1998, he was described as having the face and demeanour of a poker player. \"The eyes say nothing, the straight-set mouth betrays no emotion. He does not believe in small talk. Yet the runs have piled up in front of him like piles of chips.\"\n\nIndeed they did, for he finished his career with an aggregate of 6,744 in Test cricket at the highly respectable average of 44.66. He struck 16 hundreds.\n\nBut some questioned his commitment to the esprit de corps. In the harsh opinion of Mike Gatting, at the time an England selector, \"Graham Thorpe only brings runs to the table.\" Dispirited and run down, Thorpe excused himself from a winter of international cricket in 1999-2000.\n\nA good many top-class cricketers were able to leave their problems beyond the boundary when they went out to bat or bowl; Shane Warne, who bowled at Thorpe throughout his career and rated his batting, was the obvious example. Thorpe, however, was unable to shake off personal difficulties.\n\n\"Of all the players I played with, he was the one whose state of mind most affected his play,\" wrote his England colleague Mike Atherton. \"A happy, contented Graham Thorpe is a world-class player. If something is eating away at him, he cannot put it to the back of his mind and concentrate on his cricket.\"\n\nGraham Paul Thorpe was born in Farnham, Surrey, on August 1 1969 and was playing with men for his village at the age of 13. While at Weydon School, and then at Farnham Sixth Form College, where he was taking a PE diploma, he was invited to nets at the Oval. There, he came under the watch of Micky Stewart and Geoff Arnold, two old-school England cricketers who nurtured his development.\n\nRemarkably, Thorpe had learnt to bat left-handed as a boy even though he was naturally a right-hander. The reason for this was that it became harder for his two older brothers to get him out in the family garden, which had a shorter boundary on the leg side. He never changed his stance again.\n\nIn 1988 he made his debut for Surrey and he was in the England side five years later. After two defeats against Australia in 1993, the selectors called up Thorpe for the third Test, at Trent Bridge. There, he made an unbeaten 114, becoming the first England player to score a century on his debut since Frank Hayes against West Indies 20 years earlier.\n\nA broken thumb kept him out of the final Test of the series and he was dropped briefly the following year, but otherwise was one of few regular selections in a weak era for English cricket.\n\nThorpe batted well against spin on the sub-continent, which not many contemporaries succeeded in doing. He made a century against Pakistan at Lahore in 2000 which included just one four, a rare occurrence indeed, but he could also strike the ball expansively and deployed the sweep shot particularly well. He made his highest Test score, an unbeaten 200, against New Zealand in 2002. This came off 231 balls, a quick rate of scoring then as now.\n\nHe had to contend with a rampant Australian side, full of fine bowlers, throughout his career, which, perhaps inevitably, resulted in his \"carrying a lot of baggage\", as Warne put it.\n\n\"Andrew Strauss played in an England side that won his first eight Test matches,\" said Thorpe. \"The first eight I played, six of them were defeats. It is totally different to come into a winning team. I've played in several different eras for England and we have never had that luxury.\"\n\nNo sooner had he been discarded by the selectors, just before the series of 2005, than England regained the Ashes. He had won his 100th cap against Bangladesh earlier that summer, the management seemingly finding room for sentiment in their selection, and he did make some runs, but Pietersen and Ian Bell were now clearly preferred in the middle order.\n\nOn his home ground at the Oval, Thorpe remained a popular figure. After he dropped out of the tour in 2002-03 his return to Test cricket the following summer was marked by a standing ovation. He went on to score 124, propelling England to victory over South Africa.\n\nHe played for Surrey until 2005, scoring 21,937 runs in all first-class cricket at 45.04, not dissimilar to his Test average, which showed how well he adapted to the international game. In one-day cricket he made 2,380 runs for England at 37.18.\n\nThorpe's post-playing career encompassed some media work, writing an autobiography and working as a specialist batting coach and assistant coach for New South Wales, and then for England from 2010 until 2022, when he was sacked along with Chris Silverwood, the coach, following another heavy defeat in Australia.\n\nBizarrely, he filmed the players partying at the end of the series and the footage, including Tasmanian police telling leading players to go to bed following a complaint about \"intoxicated people\", ended up on the website of the Sydney Morning Herald. Officers had apparently been called because Thorpe lit a cigar in an indoor space.\n\nThorpe applied to be head coach of Middlesex at Lord's, but was overlooked. He was subsequently appointed coach of Afghanistan, but shortly afterwards, in May 2022, his family announced that he was seriously ill and receving treatment in hospital, with an unclear prognosis.\n\nThere was always an anti-establishment, non-conformist streak to Thorpe's character, which England had to manage carefully. He deliberately flouted dress codes and, although not a troublemaker, he viewed authority with suspicion. At one stage of his life an anti-monarchist, he none the less accepted the appointment of MBE for services to the game.\n\nThorpe was badly affected by the death of Graham Kersey, his Surrey team mate and friend, after a car crash in 1997. He had a much-publicised and messy divorce from his first wife, Nicky, following his infidelity. They had a son and a daughter, access to whom was denied to him when his marriage broke up. He is survived by them and by his second wife, Amanda, and their daughter.\n\nGraham Thorpe, born August 1 1969, death announced August 5 2024", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8259693448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:18:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:18:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:17:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/cricket/graham-thorpe-former-england-cricketer-and-coach-dies-at-55-news/article68487615.ece", "title": "Graham Thorpe, former England cricketer and coach, passes away at 55", "body": "The former England cricketer and coach Graham Thorpe has died at the age of 55, the England and Wales Cricket Board announced on Monday.\n\n\"There seem to be no appropriate words to describe the deep shock we feel at Graham's death,\" the ECB said in a statement.\n\n\"More than one of England's finest-ever batters, he was a beloved member of the cricket family and revered by fans all over the world.\n\n\"His skill was unquestioned, and his abilities and achievements across a 13-year international career brought so much happiness to his team-mates and England and Surrey CCC supporters alike.\n\n\"Later, as a coach, he guided the best England men's talent to some incredible victories across all formats of the game.\n\n\"The cricket world is in mourning today. Our hearts go out to his wife Amanda, his children, father Geoff, and all of his family and friends during this unimaginably difficult time.\n\n\"We will always remember Graham for his extraordinary contributions to the sport.\"\n\nThorpe played 100 Tests for England between 1993 and 2005, as well as 82 one-day internationals.\n\nALSO READ | SL vs India, 2nd ODI: India gets caught in Vandersay's web as Sri Lanka takes 1-0 lead in series\n\nA stylish left-handed batter, he scored 6,744 Test runs for England, including 16 centuries.\n\nHe played a further 189 first-class matches for Surrey and in all scored 49 first-class centuries, averaging 45.04, before his retirement in 2005.\n\nThorpe's playing days concluded with a shift to coaching. He began in Australia, nurturing talents like Steve Smith and David Warner at New South Wales. In 2010, he joined the England setup as a batting coach.\n\nMost recently, he served as assistant coach during the disastrous Ashes tour last winter. England's 4-0 defeat triggered a management overhaul, resulting in Thorpe, head coach Chris Silverwood, and director of cricket Ashley Giles losing their positions as the England and Wales Cricket
